story:
Who we are

The Ontario Beekeepers Association


What we want

To stop the recent serious decline in bee population in Ontario


Why we want to do that 

Neonicotinoid pesticides have been confirmed by Health Canada to be the cause of recent bee kills in Ontario and Quebec in both 2012 and 2013. We want Ontario to suspend the use of these pesticides on field crops in Ontario pending further study, just as Europe has done. Bees and beekeepers cannot survive another year of pesticide applications. 

Please, listen to this CBC radio interview which contains an emotional plea by Ontario beekeeper Dave Shuitt to understand the gravity of this issue.


How we want to do that

We want to create a, short, powerful documentary film about a third-generation Ontario beekeeper named Tom Congdon. Tom will tell his story in a way that puts a human face on the problem of the recent losses of bees . We hope his story, shared widely, will increase public pressure on provincial legislators to suspend the use of neonicotinoid. And we need them to understand the consequences of not banning these toxins before the end of this year to have untreated corn available for the next planting season. 


The Ask 

We need petition signatures and letters to MPP’s and the Premier. We’re fighting worldwide lobbying efforts by multinational pesticide corporations like Bayer and Syngenta.  So we need your help raising money to make a short documentary video about the deadly effect neonicotinoid pesticides are having on bee populations. The petition to ban these pesticides in Ontario already has 50,000+ signatures, but we need many, many more people to voice their support for Ontario bees and beekeepers. 


The Documentary 

You probably already know that bees are a vital pillar of the ecosystem  and without them, the whole food chain is at risk of collapse. You probably know that their numbers are in perilous decline . You might even have heard that neonicotinoids are a major cause of declining bee populations. But not everyone knows this. That's why we want to get the word out. That's why we want to create a compelling, short, shareable documentary video that gets the public motivated to support the suspension of neonicotinoid pesticides. 

We know that there are many factors contributing to declining bee populations, from bee pests, disease increased urbanization to climate change. The point is, neonicotinoids are weakening colonies making them more susceptible to these causes. These systemic pesticides are also contaminating our soil and our water. And suspending their use is something we can and must do. We've got an opportunity to take action. We know what we need to do, we just need to convince our elected representatives that they must take action if they are to save our bees and preserve so much of our local food that relies on bees for pollination. 

Premier Wynne, who is also our Minister of Agriculture, will be making a decision about the continued use of neonicotinoids very soon.  We want to make sure she knows that this is an issue their constituents care about. We're concerned that if there isn't enough support for suspending it's use, the Premier will accede to the powerful lobbying being done by agribusiness interests: Bayer, the Grain Farmers of Ontario and others who profit from the continued overuse and application of these pesticides. We need to get the real story and facts out there by any means.  


This is Tom Congdon


Here's Tom being interviewed by the CBC. 

He's a third-generation beekeeper. He's witnessed first-hand the effect that neonicotinoids are having on bees, and both he and many prominent scientists agree, these pesticides are killing bees worldwide. Ever since their introduction, 70% of the tested bees tested positive for traces of the pesticide.

The European Union has suspended the use of neonicotinoids pending further study. We want Canada to do the same, and we'd like to start right here in Ontario. 

Here's a quick excerpt of a talk we had with Tom recently:

"My grandfather started this business in 1916, right here in this house. My father still helps out with the bees sometimes. He’s 74, and that’s what he loves, interacting with the bees. Back when he was younger, in the 1960’s, they had a similar problem with a phosphate-based pesticide named Alderin. It decimated the bee populations so badly that he had to buy out another beekeeper up in Wellington County to stay in business. The pesticide was eventually withdrawn from use after it turned up in tomatoes on the shelves of supermarkets."

-Tom Congdon, 3rd Generation Ontario Beekeeper



How We'll Use The Documentary

We intend to seed the short video on social networks using all of our partner organizations to get the word out. We want to use the video to drive people to sign our online petition and to commit to writing a letter to their MPs and MPPs. We understand that parliament and the Ontario legislature don't pay that much attention to online petitions, but do get motivated by real, physical letters. So, as we establish online signatures, we'll ask people to print sign and mail real letters to their local elected officials. We're confident that if we can get a 500 hundred or so letters in each riding, this will become an issue the politicians cannot ignore. 



How the money will be spent

We've found some talented filmmakers who've agreed to work at minimal cost to make this video. We've got a few respected marketing professionals volunteering on this project. We have musicians ready to score the piece at cost. We estimate, to make a truly beautiful, compelling, touching and motivating video, we need somewhere between $15,000 and $20,000.  

Indigogo's take is 9%, so we're setting the goal at $20,000. 

Anything that comes in after that will be used to (in order)

  • Promote the video and petition
  • Invest in more research into the chronic effects of neonicotinoids
If we don't reach our goal but come close, we'll try to raise the difference elsewhere, or we'll channel this funding straight into promotion of the petition and more research


Urgency

Premier Wynne will be meeting with her advisors and her caucus soon.  so we've got to have something wrapped up and out there for the public to get excited about well before that. Even more pressing, as the weather gets colder the bees will not be flying.  If we want to collect any footage of Tom working with his hives in-situ, we need to move quickly. 


Learn More

Bee colony collapse affects us all. Learn more about the issue and tell your friends how serious this problem is. Here are some links that you can use to spread the word:

  • Here's a scientific paper on the impact of neonicotinoids
  • Here's a progressive farmer's perspective on the issue
  • Here's our (the Ontario Beekeepers Association's) website and Facebook Page
  • Here's the online petition
  • Here's the CBC Radio Interview with beekeeper Dave Shuitt and Ontario Beekeepers Association president Dan Davidson mentioned before
  • Here's the CBC Television piece that features Tom Congdon

story:
The Issue

The vast water reserves of the Heartland are urgently threatened by the plans of Chinese mining company Azarga Uranium Corporation.  The Madison, Inyan Kara, Deadwood, and Minnelusa aquifers, which lie under thousands of square miles of North Dakota, South Dakota, Wyoming, and Montana, require our immediate action if they are to be protected for future use.

Azarga is on the verge of initiating the proposed Dewey-Burdock Uranium project in the Black Hills of South Dakota, which would extract yellowcake Uranium (U-238)  directly within the water-bearing aquifers. This scientifically uncertain process will leak radioactive Uranium, Arsenic, Selenium, Radium and Lead into the aquifers and pollute surface and ground waters permanently, rendering the waters toxic to all life.

The Black Hills Clean Water Alliance, a non-profit organization based in South Dakota, has been founded by local citizens specifically in response to this critical issue.  Our purpose is to educate the public and raise awareness about the dangers of this proposed In-Situ leach mine. Our goal is to immediately stop Azarga from proceeding with its impending mining plans on our homeland.  

In addition to the toxic pollution of our lands, Azarga plans to sell the extracted Uranium on the open global market. 

We will not let foreign companies profit from pillaging our strategic mineral reserves and selling them to foreign entities who could conceivable create weapons of mass destruction, while simultaneously destroying the precious waters of the Heartland of America. 

This Campaign
To inform the public about this urgent issue, the Clean Water Alliance has created this 30 second public service announcement for broadcasting on local television stations in South Dakota during news hours. 

We are now at a critical juncture and need your help to raise $1,200 for immediate airtime of the video in this campaign.  

On August 18th there will be a public hearing in front of The Atomic Safety and Licensing Board of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) at Mueller Civic Center in Hot Springs, South Dakota, and it is vital that we get as many people there as possible to voice their concerns and opposition to this dangerous project.

If we raise more than $1,200, the Clean Water Alliance will use that money to pay for this public service announcement to be broadcasted as many times as possible before and after the public hearing.

We have been fighting in conjunction with the Lakota people and local ranchers for several years to protect our precious waters. Your generous contributions of any amount will go a long way to keep the vital waters of the Heartland safe! 

You can also help us by sharing this campaign with others and spreading the word.

For more information on the issue and other ways to take action by lobbying your Congressional representatives please see our website at:


http://www.sdcleanwateralliance.org

Join the Clean Water Alliance email mailing list.

Follow us on Facebook!!

Email:

    nobhuranium@gmail.com

OR:

    Clean Water Alliance

    P.O. Box 591

    Rapid City, South Dakota 57709

story:
TEN*D

DONATE 10 DOLLARS, TELL 10 PEOPLE, TEND THE WORLD TOGETHER

connecting recreation conservation & inspiration

It may not always be obvious, but nature is the foundation of a healthy life and a vibrant world. Nature is where we all begin and end, its where we get our food and medicine, our resources and our inspiration and peace. Its easy to overlook, but we all need clean water, fresh air, sunshine and nutritious food to survive. More than that, people everywhere turn to nature on a daily bases to stay healthy, happy and connected to a feeling of something greater.

People like to walk in parks, have pets, go for picnics, golf, garden, go fishing, travel, visit spas, ride bikes, run and 10,000 other things that can only be done because of nature. Nature  helps and heals us in more ways than we recognize. Without nature we don't feel whole, we don't feel human. Even though these needs are universal, most people don't recognize just how the very pastimes and recreations they love are connected to the greater ecological state of the world, and the health of billions of other people. Just because you don't see the connection, doesn't mean its not there.

Here is what we are going to do: with strong research and clear reasoning, we will identify the top 10 groups of nature users (people who enjoy & benifit nature), and we give them all 10 clear ways to get educated and active in the world's 10 most eco-critical projects. We will work with the world's top 10 most influential ecological organizations to define and simplify the global top 10 core issues and the 1 core pathway to change each. All this will be shared through 10 different outcomes including our social network, non-profit book, consumer incentive programs, apps, an on-line TV channel and more. We have the talent and connections to make it happen, what we need is your support: good hearts, interested minds... and some cash to give it fuel!

Our commitment is to always keep things simple: always simple lists, simple steps, simple actions. Always the most essential information and ways to get engaged that actually create an impact. Never more than 10 items to pay attention to or chose from, never more than 10 issues to tend to.

We promise that our education and impact steps will always be presented to people in practical, meaningful and personal ways. Nothing fancy, nothing complicated, and always a two-way street: when you give you get, when you get you give. When you buy a bike, a picnic cooler, or plant a garden, we will to work with the products and people that support you to help you give back in the process.

Our goal is to connect people to a sense of responsibility for the natural world, while they are engaged in their most favorite pastimes, products, and hobbies. It's easy and it makes sense - and it is not a conservation movement built on guilt and doom. It is built on remembering what we all love to do... go outside and play! (In one way or another.)

This project will take 4 years to completely develop and deliver, and our goals span a 10 year period... but we know we can begin to create our first results within a year. To begin to engage the corporate sponsors and ecological organizations that have shown interest in partnership, we need to raise $130,000 by the end of January 2013.

 

Here is what we want from you:

donate ten dollars and ask ten friends to do the same!

Give $10, and tell 10 people. We need you to send emails, post on Facebook, tweet and text. This how we will enrich the world by helping people to take simple steps that will change the world dramatically in the next 10 years.

 

WANT TO LEARN MORE?

To learn more about how we expect to impact 100 million people in 10 years and the 10 ways we will do it, check out our website and learn more about our mission, team and 10 objectives....

www.ten-d.com

 

PLEASE DONATE $10 TODAY, AND ASK 10 FRIENDS TO DO THE SAME:

DONATE 10, TELL 10

and together we will help:

*fishermen & farmers to get engaged in water quality and preserving wild fish stocks

*gardeners & golfers advocate against toxic pesticides and soil contamination

*spa goers and health-food shoppers to preserve the rare botanical regions where their favorite products are sourced

*people who like weekend picnics, barbeques and parks, to increase the number of green spaces in urban centers

*create an “app” that identifies the Top Ten Eco-critical Issues are, how they are being managed, how you can make a difference, and watch the changes unfolding everyday on your mobile device

*educate world leaders on the importance of conservation, wild spaces, biodiversity in securing the health and financial future of their nations

*eco-tours and animal encounters to raise awareness and inspire preservation of endangered species and reduce habitat loss

*all this and so much more…. Help people to become powerful agents of change while they take part in their favorite pastimes and activities.
story_txt:
TEN*D
DONATE 10 DOLLARS, TELL 10 PEOPLE, TEND THE WORLD TOGETHER
connecting recreation conservation & inspiration
It may not always be obvious, but nature is the foundation of a healthy life and a vibrant world. Nature is where we all begin and end, its where we get our food and medicine, our resources and our inspiration and peace. Its easy to overlook, but we all need clean water, fresh air, sunshine and nutritious food to survive. More than that, people everywhere turn to nature on a daily bases to stay healthy, happy and connected to a feeling of something greater.
People like to walk in parks, have pets, go for picnics, golf, garden, go fishing, travel, visit spas, ride bikes, run and 10,000 other things that can only be done because of nature. Nature  helps and heals us in more ways than we recognize. Without nature we don't feel whole, we don't feel human. Even though these needs are universal, most people don't recognize just how the very pastimes and recreations they love are connected to the greater ecological state of the world, and the health of billions of other people. Just because you don't see the connection, doesn't mean its not there.
Here is what we are going to do: with strong research and clear reasoning, we will identify the top 10 groups of nature users (people who enjoy & benifit nature), and we give them all 10 clear ways to get educated and active in the world's 10 most eco-critical projects. We will work with the world's top 10 most influential ecological organizations to define and simplify the global top 10 core issues and the 1 core pathway to change each. All this will be shared through 10 different outcomes including our social network, non-profit book, consumer incentive programs, apps, an on-line TV channel and more. We have the talent and connections to make it happen, what we need is your support: good hearts, interested minds... and some cash to give it fuel!
Our commitment is to always keep things simple: always simple lists, simple steps, simple actions. Always the most essential information and ways to get engaged that actually create an impact. Never more than 10 items to pay attention to or chose from, never more than 10 issues to tend to.
We promise that our education and impact steps will always be presented to people in practical, meaningful and personal ways. Nothing fancy, nothing complicated, and always a two-way street: when you give you get, when you get you give. When you buy a bike, a picnic cooler, or plant a garden, we will to work with the products and people that support you to help you give back in the process.
Our goal is to connect people to a sense of responsibility for the natural world, while they are engaged in their most favorite pastimes, products, and hobbies. It's easy and it makes sense - and it is not a conservation movement built on guilt and doom. It is built on remembering what we all love to do... go outside and play! (In one way or another.)
This project will take 4 years to completely develop and deliver, and our goals span a 10 year period... but we know we can begin to create our first results within a year. To begin to engage the corporate sponsors and ecological organizations that have shown interest in partnership, we need to raise $130,000 by the end of January 2013.
 
Here is what we want from you:
donate ten dollars and ask ten friends to do the same!
Give $10, and tell 10 people. We need you to send emails, post on Facebook, tweet and text. This how we will enrich the world by helping people to take simple steps that will change the world dramatically in the next 10 years.
 
WANT TO LEARN MORE?
To learn more about how we expect to impact 100 million people in 10 years and the 10 ways we will do it, check out our website and learn more about our mission, team and 10 objectives....
www.ten-d.com
 
PLEASE DONATE $10 TODAY, AND ASK 10 FRIENDS TO DO THE SAME:
DONATE 10, TELL 10
and together we will help:
*fishermen & farmers to get engaged in water quality and preserving wild fish stocks
*gardeners & golfers advocate against toxic pesticides and soil contamination
*spa goers and health-food shoppers to preserve the rare botanical regions where their favorite products are sourced
*people who like weekend picnics, barbeques and parks, to increase the number of green spaces in urban centers
*create an “app” that identifies the Top Ten Eco-critical Issues are, how they are being managed, how you can make a difference, and watch the changes unfolding everyday on your mobile device
*educate world leaders on the importance of conservation, wild spaces, biodiversity in securing the health and financial future of their nations
*eco-tours and animal encounters to raise awareness and inspire preservation of endangered species and reduce habitat loss
*all this and so much more…. Help people to become powerful agents of change while they take part in their favorite pastimes and activities.

story:
I am a stay-at-home mother living in the small town of Sandwich, Illinois.  My husband, Bob, and I have been married 23 years.  We have 4 children; Scott, age 16, Ethan, age 13, Claire, age 11, and Joey, age 9.  When Ethan was 3, he was diagnosed with severe autism.  After Claire and Joey were born, they were both diagnosed with autism around the same age.

 

We have lived in the same 3-bedroom home for the last 18 years.  Our home is starting to require some serious improvements, the most severe being destruction and removal of black mold that is growing in our attic.  This is not healthy for anyone; least of all autistic children who are more prone to illness than others.  We also have very old, damaged carpet that needs replacement, as well as several old, leaky windows.  Our air conditioning is 20 years old, and is ready to give up the ghost, as well.  Our daughter, Claire, suffers from severe eczema as well as autism, and must have air conditioning when it is hot to keep her eczema under control.

 

Our debt is steadily mounting, and it has now topped $50,000.  I have tried repeatedly to get a job, but I can't find anything that will allow me to work while my kids are at school, and day care for special needs children is non-existent in this area.  They require one-on-one, round-the-clock care.  Though we live below poverty level, we have never accepted help from the government.  I am only asking for help now as an emergency.  

 

We live very meagerly; we only eat out once at month (at McDonald's) and my husband and I NEVER go out.  We have 2 vehicles, both of which are from the year 2000.  We plan to drive both of those into the ground.  We do not have fancy clothes or fancy furniture.  We still use most of the furniture we had when we got married.

 

I am begging for this help for my family; you can't imagine the burden it would lift off my family to able to update our home to make it safe and healthy for our children.  I would do anything for my children, but we live on my husband's income and we just don't have any extra to put into our home.

 

Thank you so much for any help you can give us.  I pray that you will find us worthy of help.  Bless you.

All our products are made by hand, HOME MADE, and are completely natural, and so they can not harm your health, protect your children from allergic reactions and difficulty breathing. Our products are entirely made ​​from natural resources such as: fruit lemon, salt, citric acid, alcohol vinegar, essential oils and food colors. For our products we have documentation that confirms all compositions that are listed.


The average household contains about 62 toxic chemicals, say environmental experts. We’re exposed to them routinely — from the phthalates in synthetic fragrances to the noxious fumes in oven cleaners. Ingredients in common household products have been linked to asthma, cancer, reproductive disorders, hormone disruption and neurotoxicity.


Manufacturers argue that in small amounts these toxic ingredients aren’t likely to be a problem, but when we’re exposed to them routinely, and in combinations that haven’t been studied, it’s impossible to accurately gauge the risks. While a few products cause immediate reactions from acute exposure (headaches from fumes, skin burns from accidental contact), different problems arise with repeated contact. Chronic exposure adds to the body’s “toxic burden” — the number of chemicals stored in its tissues at a given time.


Beware of unregulated "greenwash" claims on labels! Terms such as "natural" and "eco-friendly" shouldn't be equated with safety unless they're backed up with specific ingredient information, such as "solvent-free," "no petroleum-based ingredients," "no phosphates," etc. "Non-toxic" has no official definition, so unless a third party has verified this claim, it is not considered meaningful. And don't believe "organic" ingredients in cleaning and other chemical products are any safer than other substances. Although "organic" in the grocery store refers to foods grown without synthetic pesticides, in chemistry it refers to chemicals that are carbon-based, including some VOCs (volatile organic compounds) that release harmful fumes and may cause brain damage or cancer.Additionally, watch out for products labeled organic. 


"Lorem Artis" is the first, and so far the only producer of natural cleaning products in Croatia. It was founded with the aim to better inform people and prove to them that for a clean home is not necessary to use harsh chemicals that harm to people and the environment. Cleaners working on own recipes, which are formed as a product of research after a family member got an allergic reaction to cleaning chemicals.Products are suitable for people with allergies, asthma, and of course, all those who do not want use harmful chemicals in your home.We have the resources needed so that we may place our products throughout our country,and in some beautifull dreams in the rest of the world.

Our products are:  1. cleaning glass surfaces, lavender, lemon, orange

                               2. universal toilet sanitary cleaner- lemon

                               3. lemon gel for dishwasher, and also universal cleaner

we hope that the good people recognize our good idea and help us to conduct our idea into action.

If donors want more information about us, please contact us via e-mail loremartis1@gmail.com. . Thank's everyone

10 000 dollars to pay to:

1.EQUIPMENT and RENTAL

2.Press & Publicity

3. To work with bio&bio organization ( http://www.biobio.hr/ )

4. To buy packaging and materials for our products ( we need 350 unit for each product every month )

   A. - price of packaging for HOME MADE-product for glass surface = $ 301

    A1.- price of material for HOME MADE-product for glass surface= $ 269 

    a. >VNEGAR: 17,5 LITERS

    b. >ESENTIAL OIL: 350 MILLILITERS

    c. >FOOD COLOR: 350 MILLILITERS

    d. >TRANSPORT BOX: 60 pcs

    e. >DELIVERY: $ 100

   

 B- price of packaging fro HOME MADE-product WC sanitar= $ 301

    B1.- price of material for HOME MADE-product WC sanitar = $ 611 

    a.>LEMON: 95 KILO

    b.>SALT: 52,5 KILO

    c.>CITRIC ACID: 52,5 KILO

    d>VINEGAR: 52,5 LITERS

    c.>TRANSPORT BOX: 60 pcs

    e.> DELIVERY: $ 125

    

C - price of packaging for HOME MADE-product Gel for mach.dishwash.= $ 301

    C1.- price of material for HOME MADE-product Gel for mach dishwash. = $ 748

    a.>LEMON: 140 KILO

    b.>SALT: 87,5 KILO

    c.>VINEGAR: 87 LITERS

    d.>TRANSPORT BOX: 60 pcs

    e.>DELIVERY: $ 170

    

TOTAL = $ 2998 for one month to deliver our customer buyer (  needed for 3 months )

The essence of these calculations is that our first three sales is with deferred payment of three months. Therefore, we need 10,000 dollars to be able to start a business with a reputable buyer- www.biobio.hr

Cooperation with this organization give us a great potential for our project


Thank you for your support in bringing our new concept to reality!
If you find that you can't make a contibution, no problem! Please spread the word about our campiagn as we need all the help we can get! Feel free to use indiegogo's sharing tools to help make your voice even louder! :)

story:
The Fundraiser:

We are now concluding a 2,000 nautical mile Kite and Stand Up Paddle from Tonga to Australia.

View Route

http://www.leisureactivistgroup.com/content/Exp...

All in an effort to raise funds for the retrofit of S.V. Moana to become "a collaboration to design and promote next-generation, sustainable, municipal-scale utilities." It is our hope to further educate people on a "model that incorporates proven and emerging technologies to reduce fossil fuel dependency, create jobs, close landfills, and anchor renewable energy systems."

How it Works

http://www.leisureactivistgroup.com/content/Gip...


Help Us Be the First:

With your help we can be the first existing model to showcase the variety of technolagies available today to power municipalities and step away from fossil fuel dependancy.

Documentary Themes:

1. Taking on an adventure never attempted before

2. A group of friends completely un-sponsored doing what they believe in

3. Showcasing what we have at our disposal and how we can keep it

Book Theme:

 

A collection of images and Capt/crew logs

Ben's eye:

http://www.leisureactivistgroup.com/content/Bens-Photo-Gallery/55.aspx

Stephs pen:

http://sailingsafari.tumblr.com/page/2

Adrian's Rants:

http://www.leisureactivistgroup.com/content/Cap...

Our Team

http://www.leisureactivistgroup.com/content/Tea...

Ben
First Mate:

"Ben is "all about getting out there and seeing the world, enjoy life and make the most of it.”

He’s a keen surfer/kiter or when it comes down to it, any sport in the water. Currently enjoying life in French Polynesia, he’s taking every moment to follow these passions whilst immersing himself in the culture and loving every minute.

His background consists of a Postgraduate Degree in Geography and Environmental Management from the University of Otago in New Zealand. Since completing his studies he has worked all over the world in all sorts of roles from picking apples to surveying the Australian Outback, from catering weddings, developing an advertising company to working on yachts in a variety of Oceans.

"Just by looking at the current state of the world it is important that the grommets coming up through the ranks have an understanding of a sustainable lifestyle, there is too much waste going on in the world and if it carries on like that there won’t be much left for anyone else to enjoy, the expedition will highlight the cause, spread the word and all the while we will be having a blast and I’m stoked to be involved."
Steph
Deckhand

(for the daily adventures of Ben and Steph you can enjoy http://sailingsafari.tumblr.com/page/2

Steph’s first memory of boats was when she was a fully, fledged captain of her own rig.
“She was a dream, just kept on purring, never needed a moments work, just living as if wanting solely, to serve her purpose of being a pleasure cruiser and doing the best she could for me”.
The HMS Joy, was a one of a kind, a tear sets in her eye just thinking back to her.
“The red, yellow and white combination of colors always shone as bright as the first rays of sunshine on a clear day. She made me the sailor I am today and made my job as captain a reality too good to be true. She successfully got me through storms that make a tropical cyclone seem like a day at a resort, together we glided our way through millponds, navigated icebergs and rocky shores without a single bruise and moored in some of the worlds most secluded and stunning locations”.
Regrettably, her growing body surpassed the 30cm plastic motorboat and as she pushed her off down the tub watching Polly Pocket take the helm, she knew she was going to have to let her go and move on to bigger and better crafts.
She never quite got over losing her and so filled the void in between the ages of 5 and 25 learning and then studying to become a primary school teacher: pushing the dream of sailing once more away. She spent three years teaching in a remote outback school in Australia, as far away from the sea as she could get. The sand there was only red and any water was infested with crocodiles, she needed to squash this dream once and for all. Alas, 2011 was a year when she realized there were some real holes in her credentials as a captain.
“When I realized that there was more to boats than pushing them along with your hand, I went back to basics and enrolled in a super yacht stewardess course. I learnt to fold toilet paper, fight fires, tie three whole knots and make a mean floral arrangement”.
In other words we now have a qualified person to fashion a sweet arrangement out of seaweed to brighten up the joint or fold their toilet paper into a swan. She has been paddle boarding for an intense three weeks now and while on shaky legs she watches, kite surfers and surfers from afar, the key to her success. However, limited her skills may be, she loves to travel and learn skills and knowledge that she can use to help herself or more importantly pass on to other eager ears.
She understands the consequence of not creating a culture where little sprouts appreciate a sustainable lifestyle. When a child threw plastic bottles on the ground at school and told her ‘it does not matter because it will just blow away ‘ she recognized the importance of this statement and her and her class used all the plastic bottles in the community to make a Christmas tree.
A wise Kiwi told her of some graffiti he saw written on the wall of a tram
‘work less, spend less, and live more’
“I think it is a pretty fitting reason for why I am doing what I am doing and what message I would like to pass on.”

Nick
Temp Deckhand

Nick is presently employed by the UN as a Climate Change advisor, with a background in Oceanography and Sustainable Development.
He is one person who has taken his love of our planet to the serious level.
En-route to his current position, Nick spent a great deal of his time playing in the mountains and Ocean.
An avid kiter, surfer, snowboarder and all 'round adventurer, Nick is an excellent addition to our passage.
We are very pleased to have Nick aboard, even if we only get him for 2 weeks.

Adrian
Capt.

A Canadian born outdoor enthusiast, with over 12 years experience in both hospitality and the action sports industry—snowboarding, surfing, wakeboarding, sailing and kite boarding. A PADI Instructor and M.C.A. Master of Yachts 200-ton unlimited Adrian brings with him a wide breadth of nautical experience from 10ft tenders to 200ft yachts and a deep love for working and playing on and in the water.
With experience ranging from work as a private action sports guide, to Captaining yacht based youth programs his ocean expertise knows no bounds… After making the decision to focus on his true love—enjoying the ocean—he now resides in the South Pacific aboard our mobile office.

 

How you can help

Donate and your tax-deductible gift will help us complete our historic and beneficial mission. 100% of your money will go to direct expenses of the expedition and implementing the GIP Ocean Ambassador Program. We are raising money two ways: corporate sponsors and individual donations (like yours). 

Retrofit:
2 x 13 KW Ac electric outboard motors 19,000.00
2 x 10 KW h lithium battery packs     14,000.00
including chargers
2 x 5 KW generators (AC)              6,000.00
2 KW solar panels & MPPT controller   5,000.00

Switches, cables, plugs and fuses
all prewired                          1,000.00

2 x Wind generators 4,000

Bio Fuel Farm (mini model) 5,000

Hydro Generator 10,000

total 79,000

(remaining 21,000 for additional costs of yacht ie. operation, customs, immigration fees, general maintenence etc)

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Other than funding, we could greatly benefit by people who are producing any and all of these products to showcase on our model.

So if you make or sell:

Solar pannels

Wind Generators

Hydro generators

Electric engines

Bio Fuels

etc
story_txt:
The Fundraiser:
We are now concluding a 2,000 nautical mile Kite and Stand Up Paddle from Tonga to Australia.
View Route
http://www.leisureactivistgroup.com/content/Exp...
All in an effort to raise funds for the retrofit of S.V. Moana to become "a collaboration to design and promote next-generation, sustainable, municipal-scale utilities." It is our hope to further educate people on a "model that incorporates proven and emerging technologies to reduce fossil fuel dependency, create jobs, close landfills, and anchor renewable energy systems."
How it Works
http://www.leisureactivistgroup.com/content/Gip...

story:
Here's The Story

Malaysia has been recently hit by a massive flood and heavy rain. Specifically in the East Coast, lives and homes have been affected. 

As victims pick up their pieces to mend back their lives, we at Food Tour Malaysia, would like to rally contributors to help aid this massive effort. To date,

  • Relief work to cost more than RM1 billion (USD$285 million)
  • More than 100,000 people have been evacuated to refuge centres.
  • The cost to fix broken infrastructure in Kelantan alone is estimated at RM200 million (USD$57 million).
  • Power supply has been affected at most areas.

Food Tour Malaysia Plans To...

We are rallying our friends, families and guests to see how you can help us, to help the victims. We plan to:

  • Raise money and contribute to the re-development of the lives affected
  • Use the money to purchase food items, medical supplies or groceries for the victims
  • Donate the sum of money for helicopter movements to the affected area

Where Does The Money Go

We will direct the funds to either (or both): 

  • Crisis Relief Services And Training Berhad (CREST Malaysia)
  • Mercy Malaysia

Accountability

We will inform you on the total sum raised and will send the necessary receipts, pictures or documents to support our donation or purchase.

story:
Brazil is a country that boasts amazing beaches and spectacular rain forests. In addition to this, the country has a rich and diversified culture.  Even though the Brazilian economy has been growing over the last years, the class differences are vast in most parts of the country. Many areas are characterized by economic underdevelopment, educational inequality and very limited government resources for the poor, resulting in the fact that a staggering 42% of Brazilian children live in Poverty.

Many of these children are led to the streets, being abandoned because their families do not have the money to support their basic life requirements. Breaking this cycle of poverty is all but a dream for most, and many will end up working with child labour, drugs and violent crime.



Dreams are important. Although not every Brazilian child’s dream is to play football at a professional level, the sport is almost considered religion in the country that hosted the World Cup in 2014. In the past, football has given many the opportunity to escape from their brutal reality.

The opportunity to help children living in such an environment is something we just couldn’t pass up. So we decided to put our skill sets to use and create an environmentally friendly project that could benefit children’s development.

In short, we aim to install solar panels that will produce electricity for a local football field in the town of Maracajau. This electricity will provide power to the floodlights in the field, so that the local children can play football during afternoons when the sun sets. We have scheduled to implement our bachelor project in Brazil for the spring term of 2016. In addition, as future engineers this process will allow us to gain extremely valuable experience for further work. 

We feel that every step in the right direction is one step closer to creating equal opportunities for children, and although floodlights for a football field will not solve all problems, we hope it can contribute to something meaningful.

Bearing this in mind, we hope that you would like to help us make this dream a reality. All contributions, big or small, will be essential when it comes to completing this project, and we will be very grateful for every penny raised.

Thank you for taking the time to read about our project, we hope that you will follow with us for the rest of our journey towards Brazil.

Please feel free to share.

Many hands make light work. 


Our logo is made by 13 year old Pedro from Brazil.


A written report must be submitted to Bergen University College.

After the project is completed, the further operations will be handed over to the Education to be foundation.

story:
We want to change the electricity grid. You interested? 

Why it Matters

The energy landscape in North America is already in the midst of a major overhaul. Despite all the recent advancements in government policy, rebates and incentives, smart grid applications and turnkey technologies, there are still barriers to generating community solar.

Individuals and households living on low income and in areas exposed to the health impacts downstream of hydrocarbon-based energy production are often shut out of the technical, policy, and financial opportunities.

The Energy Solidarity Cooperative was formed as a response to this imperative, and we see ourselves part of a larger whole, because communities deserve local control over local resources. In reaching our fundraising goal we can prove that communities can become energy resilient and that good ideas can be supported by their communities independent of traditional, top-down financing models.

In the spirit of environmental and social justice, we are kicking off this campaign on June 5th, World Environment Day, and concluding it on July 6th, International Co-op Day!

What Your Contribution Means

So what are you supporting? As a founding contributor, your dollars are going to literally kick off a massive funding drive called a direct public offering (read more here: http://bit.ly/XiakAN) to help finance between 3 and 5 community-owned, cooperatively-run solar power projects. The direct public offering serves as an alternative to top-down financing models such as venture capital and large banks. 

We are currently partnering with schools, non-profit organizations, and community groups in Oakland, California to install systems serving as educational sites on urban rooftops or brown-field reclamations. But we won't stop there. Some of the money generated will be re-invested in more community power projects!

This IndieGoGo campaign plus the Direct Public Offering will demonstrate a viable path to community-owned solar. ESC plans to build off this foundation to develop a platform and path to community-owned energy for institutions and individuals, including both on-site and off-site community solar projects. 

Who We Are

The folks behind ESC are a dynamic team of architects, engineers, planners, policy analysts, group facilitators, educators, researchers and community leaders.

But above all, we're energy activists who believe in a different way of doing things. We'd like to fund these clean power projects in the same as they will be owned and managed—from the ground up, through grassroots involvement of people like you.

Check out the slew of exciting rewards being offered as a show of appreciation for your contribution and thanks for helping community power grow!

In solar-darity,

-ESC

 

Our Rewards:

 

Our Reward Partners:

story:
MOLOKAI: AN ISLAND LOST IN TIME AND IN A RACE AGAINST EXTINCTION

Molokai, the "real" Hawaii nobody knows. 65 miles and a world away from Honolulu. Home to our country's longest fringing reef system and the world's highest sea cliffs. A population of just 7,000 people - with over 60% identifying as native Hawaiian - but with the highest rates of poverty and unemployment in the state. An island lost in time and in a race against environmental and cultural extinction.


  • Molokai has one of highest rates of extinction in the world. It makes up less than 0.1% of U.S. land, but has over 25% of the plants and animals found on the nation's endangered species list. Because the Hawaiian archipelago is so geographically isolated, new species were introduced at a rate of only one every 100,000 years. But with the arrival of man - and especially Europeans - scientists estimate new species are being introduced at 2 million times the natural rate. As a result, native species are under constant threat from aggressive non-native species, such as the kiawe tree, a thorny relative of the mesquite native to Peru. In 1828 a single tree was planted in Honolulu. Today, it dominates the lowland ecosystems of all the islands, but especially Molokai, where it's out-competing native vegetation at an alarming rate.

  • Every year thousands of tons of topsoil smother Molokai's precious reef system, erosion caused by the human introduction of cattle, goats, deer, pigs, sugar cane, and pineapple.
  • Molokai's Native Hawaiian population faces severe economic challenges. Unemployment on the island is almost double the statewide average, and the per capita income is among the lowest in the state. Molokai also has the highest percentage of young children living in poverty. Hawaiians on the island have adapted by returning to their cultural roots, practicing traditional and sustainable substance fishing, farming and hunting to survive.
  • Molokai is under intense development pressure from international corporations which offer little beyond minimum wage work in exchange for paving over a vast array of cultural, archaeological, subsistence, environmental, agricultural, and recreational resources. For a community which does not view land as a commodity but rather as the foundation of their identity as Hawaiians, time is of the essence to develop viable, environmentally sensitive and sustainable economic alternatives.


WHAT IS THE MOLOKAI LAND TRUST?

In 2006, The Molakai Land Trust was formed as a non-profit community-based organization with a mission to conserve the island’s precious lands and return them to their natural state, protecting its unique diversity and cultural heritage for future generations. As a 501(c)(3) organization, all donations to the Molokai Land Trust are tax deductible!

Molokai Land Trust owns or manages nearly 3,000 acres of native wilderness.

  • Mokio Preserve - This 1,718 acre parcel on the dry, northwestern part of Molokai contains approximately 5 miles of rugged shoreline, remnant native coastal strand and dune ecosystems, a seasonal wetland, and several ancient Hawaiian sites, including an adze quarry and the remnants of a seasonal housing complex. In 2010, MLT's staff discovered a single specimen of the endangered ohai plant which had not been documented in the area for a 100 years. From this one plant, we were able to successfully cultivate and reestablish a new population of ohai on the preserve. Today 136 specimens thrive on the site and over 300 seedlings are ready to be replanted from our nursery stock.
  • Kawaikapu Preserve - In 2009, MLT purchased  the 196.4 acre Kawaikapu Ranch located on the wet, southeast part of Molokai. This environmentally and culturally significant land purchase stretches from sea level up to 1600 feet. The valley is rich in cultural history as the site of an ancient and extensive taro loi complex, with sites scattered throughout the lower watershed. Protected in perpetuity from development, Kawaikapu represents an opportunity to work with local residents to nurture the native plants used for cultural purposes, manage subsistence gathering, and reestablish and protect the native forest.

  • Mo'omomi Preserve - The 921-acre Mo'omomi Preserve is the most intact coastal beach strand and sand dune area in the main Hawaiian Islands.  Owned by The Nature Conservancy, MLT was contracted in 2010 to assist them with stewardship activities in the preserve. By protecting the dunes and beaches of Mo'omomi, MLT is safeguarding native plants found nowhere else on earth, as well as criticial endangered species habitat and nesting sites for the rare Hawaiian owl, Hawaiian monk seals, seabird nesting colonies for the wedge-tailed shearwater, and endangered green sea turtles.


  • WHAT MAKES US DIFFERENT?

    The Molokai Land Trust recognizes and values the priceless resources right here within our own community on Molokai. We know that without community support, our organization can't take on the important work necessary to preserve and restore the cultural and natural resources that make Molokai so unique. So we work proactively to create opportunities for local residents and groups to interact with the land and sustainably use its resources in traditional ways.

    •  We carefully manage traditional subsistence activities such as forest gathering, la'au lapa'au (traditional Hawaiian herbal healing), hunting and fishing.
    • Our habitat restoration projects are highly successful. We aggressively clear out non-native vegetation, reintroduced entire native plant ecosystems all at once from seedlings we propagate in our own nurseries, then protect the projects with extensive fencing, remove non-native predators, and carefully monitor the progress of each reestablished habitat.
    • We've partnered with the Molokai public schools on environmental science and service learning projects. Our goal is to give every child on Molokai the opportunity to create their own connection with the land as the kapuna (elders) did generations ago.
    • We've partnered with AmeriCorp to offer paid internships to local and native youth, bringing much needed employment to Molokai while providing valuable work experience in conservation and land management techniques.
    • We respect the vision of Molokai's kupuna (elders) and work directly with them to preserve, protect and perpetuate core Hawaiian values. We envision a wise and caring community that takes pride in its resourcefulness, self-sufficiency and resiliency, and is firmly in charge of Moloka'i resources and destiny.


      HERE ARE SOME OF THE WAYS YOUR INVESTMENT WILL HELP THE MOLOKAI LAND TRUST SAVE THE LAST OF WILD HAWAII.



      • $10 can pay to gather wild seed, germinate and grow an endangered Ohai plant in our nursery

      • $25 can pay to plant it or another native plant at our Anapuka Dune Restoration site

      • $50 can pay to put a monitoring band on one wedge-tailed shearwater chick

      • $100 can pay to remove 1 invasive kiawe tree from Mokio Preserve

      • $250 can help pay to deploy albatross decoys on Mokio Preserve. The decoys are used to attract these endangered birds to the area in order to reestablish their historic nesting grounds.

      • $500 can pay to send a class of Molokai schoolchildren to Mokio and Kawaikapu to conduct hands-on scientific surveys, experiments and service learning projects

      • $1,000 can pay for 75' of new protective fencing to expand the Anapuka Dune Restoration Project

      • $5,000 can help pay for architectural work to design a new Operations and Service Learning Center. The new Center will consolidate our operations into one centralized location, increasing our efficiency, cutting down on costs, and will help us better meet Molokai's service learning needs by putting us within 1 mile of 75% of the island's student body

      • $10,000 can help pay for engineering to build the new Operations and Service Learning Center

      • $25,000 can pay to acquire as much as 4 acres of land from private owners and protect it forever from development

      • $50,000 can fund a full-time Molokai Land Trust employee position to help with habitat restoration and assist students in service learning programs


        GIVE BACK TO GET BACK.......
        MAKE YOUR TAX-DEDUCTIBLE DONATION TODAY TO RECEIVE THESE AMAZING PERKS!


        $100 PERK

        12-month Molokai wall calendar featuring stunning images from award-winning National Geographic photographers


        $500 PERK

        Receive a signed 16x24 archival print of this amazing wave image of taken at Papahoku Beach, on the West Coast of Molokai, by acclaimed National Geographic photographer and lecturer Dewitt Jones.


        $500 PERK

        Receive a signed 16x24 archival print of this iconic wave image of taken at Papahoku Beach, on the West Coast of Molokai, by award winning National Geographic photographer Richard Cooke.


        $500 PERK

        Receive this stunning 16x24 archival print of a "heart wave" captured at Papahoku Beach, on the West Coast of Molokai, by Creative National Geographic photographer Jonathan Kingston.


        $2,500 PERK

        "Molokai, An Island In Time" This limited collectors edition of Rikki Cooke's "Moloka'i, An Island In Time" was printed in 1984 and bound by Jesus Sanchez, Hawaii's premier book binder who learned his craft in the Vatican. The spine is made of Nubian goat skin, hand tooled with gold embossed lettering, and the binding is hand-stiched. Rikki Cooke will sign a personal a message for each book that's claimed. Only 20 of these books exist in the world.
story_txt:
MOLOKAI: AN ISLAND LOST IN TIME AND IN A RACE AGAINST EXTINCTION

Molokai, the "real" Hawaii nobody knows. 65 miles and a world away from Honolulu. Home to our country's longest fringing reef system and the world's highest sea cliffs. A population of just 7,000 people - with over 60% identifying as native Hawaiian - but with the highest rates of poverty and unemployment in the state. An island lost in time and in a race against environmental and cultural extinction.
Molokai has one of highest rates of extinction in the world. It makes up less than 0.1% of U.S. land, but has over 25% of the plants and animals found on the nation's endangered species list. Because the Hawaiian archipelago is so geographically isolated, new species were introduced at a rate of only one every 100,000 years. But with the arrival of man - and especially Europeans - scientists estimate new species are being introduced at 2 million times the natural rate. As a result, native species are under constant threat from aggressive non-native species, such as the kiawe tree, a thorny relative of the mesquite native to Peru. In 1828 a single tree was planted in Honolulu. Today, it dominates the lowland ecosystems of all the islands, but especially Molokai, where it's out-competing native vegetation at an alarming rate. 
Every year thousands of tons of topsoil smother Molokai's precious reef system, erosion caused by the human introduction of cattle, goats, deer, pigs, sugar cane, and pineapple.
Molokai's Native Hawaiian population faces severe economic challenges. Unemployment on the island is almost double the statewide average, and the per capita income is among the lowest in the state. Molokai also has the highest percentage of young children living in poverty. Hawaiians on the island have adapted by returning to their cultural roots, practicing traditional and sustainable substance fishing, farming and hunting to survive.
Molokai is under intense development pressure from international corporations which offer little beyond minimum wage work in exchange for paving over a vast array of cultural, archaeological, subsistence, environmental, agricultural, and recreational resources. For a community which does not view land as a commodity but rather as the foundation of their identity as Hawaiians, time is of the essence to develop viable, environmentally sensitive and sustainable economic alternatives.

WHAT IS THE MOLOKAI LAND TRUST?
In 2006, The Molakai Land Trust was formed as a non-profit community-based organization with a mission to conserve the island’s precious lands and return them to their natural state, protecting its unique diversity and cultural heritage for future generations. As a 501(c)(3) organization, all donations to the Molokai Land Trust are tax deductible!Molokai Land Trust owns or manages nearly 3,000 acres of native wilderness.
Mokio Preserve - This 1,718 acre parcel on the dry, northwestern part of Molokai contains approximately 5 miles of rugged shoreline, remnant native coastal strand and dune ecosystems, a seasonal wetland, and several ancient Hawaiian sites, including an adze quarry and the remnants of a seasonal housing complex. In 2010, MLT's staff discovered a single specimen of the endangered ohai plant which had not been documented in the area for a 100 years. From this one plant, we were able to successfully cultivate and reestablish a new population of ohai on the preserve. Today 136 specimens thrive on the site and over 300 seedlings are ready to be replanted from our nursery stock.

Kawaikapu Preserve - In 2009, MLT purchased  the 196.4 acre Kawaikapu Ranch located on the wet, southeast part of Molokai. This environmentally and culturally significant land purchase stretches from sea level up to 1600 feet. The valley is rich in cultural history as the site of an ancient and extensive taro loi complex, with sites scattered throughout the lower watershed. Protected in perpetuity from development, Kawaikapu represents an opportunity to work with local residents to nurture the native plants used for cultural purposes, manage subsistence gathering, and reestablish and protect the native forest.

Mo'omomi Preserve - The 921-acre Mo'omomi Preserve is the most intact coastal beach strand and sand dune area in the main Hawaiian Islands.  Owned by The Nature Conservancy, MLT was contracted in 2010 to assist them with stewardship activities in the preserve. By protecting the dunes and beaches of Mo'omomi, MLT is safeguarding native plants found nowhere else on earth, as well as criticial endangered species habitat and nesting sites for the rare Hawaiian owl, Hawaiian monk seals, seabird nesting colonies for the wedge-tailed shearwater, and endangered green sea turtles.





WHAT MAKES US DIFFERENT?

The Molokai Land Trust recognizes and values the priceless resources right here within our own community on Molokai. We know that without community support, our organization can't take on the important work necessary to preserve and restore the cultural and natural resources that make Molokai so unique. So we work proactively to create opportunities for local residents and groups to interact with the land and sustainably use its resources in traditional ways.
 We carefully manage traditional subsistence activities such as forest gathering, la'au lapa'au (traditional Hawaiian herbal healing), hunting and fishing.

Our habitat restoration projects are highly successful. We aggressively clear out non-native vegetation, reintroduced entire native plant ecosystems all at once from seedlings we propagate in our own nurseries, then protect the projects with extensive fencing, remove non-native predators, and carefully monitor the progress of each reestablished habitat.

We've partnered with the Molokai public schools on environmental science and service learning projects. Our goal is to give every child on Molokai the opportunity to create their own connection with the land as the kapuna (elders) did generations ago.

We've partnered with AmeriCorp to offer paid internships to local and native youth, bringing much needed employment to Molokai while providing valuable work experience in conservation and land management techniques.

We respect the vision of Molokai's kupuna (elders) and work directly with them to preserve, protect and perpetuate core Hawaiian values. We envision a wise and caring community that takes pride in its resourcefulness, self-sufficiency and resiliency, and is firmly in charge of Moloka'i resources and destiny.


HERE ARE SOME OF THE WAYS YOUR INVESTMENT WILL HELP THE MOLOKAI LAND TRUST SAVE THE LAST OF WILD HAWAII.


$10 can pay to gather wild seed, germinate and grow an endangered Ohai plant in our nursery


$25 can pay to plant it or another native plant at our Anapuka Dune Restoration site


$50 can pay to put a monitoring band on one wedge-tailed shearwater chick


$100 can pay to remove 1 invasive kiawe tree from Mokio Preserve


$250 can help pay to deploy albatross decoys on Mokio Preserve. The decoys are used to attract these endangered birds to the area in order to reestablish their historic nesting grounds.


$500 can pay to send a class of Molokai schoolchildren to Mokio and Kawaikapu to conduct hands-on scientific surveys, experiments and service learning projects


$1,000 can pay for 75' of new protective fencing to expand the Anapuka Dune Restoration Project


$5,000 can help pay for architectural work to design a new Operations and Service Learning Center. The new Center will consolidate our operations into one centralized location, increasing our efficiency, cutting down on costs, and will help us better meet Molokai's service learning needs by putting us within 1 mile of 75% of the island's student body


$10,000 can help pay for engineering to build the new Operations and Service Learning Center


$25,000 can pay to acquire as much as 4 acres of land from private owners and protect it forever from development


$50,000 can fund a full-time Molokai Land Trust employee position to help with habitat restoration and assist students in service learning programs

GIVE BACK TO GET BACK.......MAKE YOUR TAX-DEDUCTIBLE DONATION TODAY TO RECEIVE THESE AMAZING PERKS!

"Molokai, An Island In Time" 
This limited collectors edition of Rikki Cooke's "Moloka'i, An Island In Time" was printed in 1984 and bound by Jesus Sanchez, Hawaii's premier book binder who learned his craft in the Vatican. Only 20 of these books exist in the world.

story:
The Reclamation Administration: 

Ecological Conservation Through Architectural Salvage & Reuse

Since 2011 the RA has been a primary site for news and research on building material waste prevention. Posts on projects, programs, policy, people and the amazing progress made in reclaiming beautiful materials from going to waste!

  • Over 3,000 links to inspiring stories, collaboration, and design
  • Resource pages on reuse centers, regional policy, reuse design links
  • Original content articles, featured artists, announcements, and internships

The building material reuse community is a thriving growing industry of professionals and policy-makers who are changing the world for the better! The Reclamation Administration is uniting this diverse community through daily news.

The Reclamation Administration Needs to Increase Capacity!

This free site needs capital to evolve. We need $5,000 for:

  • Publication of our First Book on reclaimed designs by the talented craftspeople featured over the years
  • New Logo and Marketing campaign to reach more readers 
  • Additional supply & demand Resource Pages to connect people to materials
  • To become a Limited Liability Corporation: The Reclamation Administration, LLC
If the funding goal isn't reached, The Reclamation Administration will continue to provide these services but at a much slower pace. There is a high demand for inspirational news on reclaimed building materials - and we want to answer the call!

The Impact

The RA is an ongoing source of inspiration for design, policy, collaboration, business, environmental issues, job creation, and education.  The RA features daily information highlighting the “Triple Bottom Line” model of sustainability.  The RA provides daily news that People, Planet, and Profit are synergistic when reclaiming building materials.

  • Social change in the form of job creation, and the establishment of Deconstruction as a Trade Skill
  •  Environmental and ecological impact through reducing the waste stream and limiting the need for consuming raw materials
  •  Financial profit from creating a new industry in harvesting and producing products from reclaimed building materials
Over 100,000 people have visited the RA since it's creation with an average of 100 new visitors a day. Over 400 readers are dedicated followers.

Risks & Challenges

The RA has been operating as a blog for over three years.  The new funds will go to registering The Reclamation Administration as a LLC. The RA is a Social Entrepreneurship – a business with a mission and we have a lot more to learn!

Here's what we have so far:

  • Over three years of support in consistent & reliable information on building material reuse
  • Partnerships with national organizations, businesses, craftspeople, and government
  • Small business graduate through Mercy Corps North West

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t contribute financially send us your news instead!  We are always looking to spread the word and hear people’s stories on reuse. Send our campaign to someone you know, take a moment to pass it on – thank you.

  • Get the word out about The Reclamation Administration
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Recycling turns things into other things , which is like magic. Who thought charcoal dust which remains at the bottom of a sack could be turned into another form of charcoal which can be used for electricity generation, heat, and cooking fuel and that is what we do at Laikipia Eco Venture.

An organization based in Nanyuki, Kenya, working towards providing a more sustainable environment for our local community , our credo is "INNOVATE RECYCLE and INSPIRE", we are made up of recycling lovers, in Kenya and the USA. So far our first recycling project is based in Nanyuki Kenya, which consists of a small factory, which is made up of a briquettes compressing machine made from scrap metal. From it we have managed to introduce smokeless charcoal to a majority of homes and hotels in Nanyuki Kenya.

The project began after a charcoal crisis hit a town called Nanyuki in Kenya, this is after the Government banned the burning of charcoal in forests this, resulted in a shortage of the fuel hence product being sold in an exorbitant price. Many homes were left without cooking fuel and they turned to using charcoal dust which is a health hazard due to the huge amount of smoke it emits, and this gave birth to our first idea of making briquettes for homes.

We bought our first briquettes machine in a neighboring town called Nyeri, and charcoal dust being readily available in Nanyuki, we immediately embarked on making this type of cooking of fuel and gradually introducing it to homes and hotels in Nanyuki, however we intend to expand and penetrate the hotel , lodges and poultry industries. This calls for churning our briquettes in all kind of attractive shapes such as the square, round, goose egg , pillow and so on, to address this, we are planning to purchase a  state of the art briquettes compressing machine.

With the assistance of St. Mary’s University California USA, we have set up a crowdfunding account in Indiegogo crowdfunding platform to raise funds which will be channeled towards purchasing of the state of the art briquettes Machine.

Risks and challenges

Below are the challenges we envisage to face when implementing our project.

PACKAGING. 
Currently we package our briquettes in used gunny bags when distributing it to homes within Nanyuki, Kenya, but we would want export our briquettes to other countries within East Africa Community and also sell our products to 5 star hotels in the region this calls for packaging our product in an attractive manner. In order to address this we are in the process of designing our gunny bags made from discarded polythene bags lying idle in our neighborhoods.

BETTER VARIATIONS.

Currently our smokeless charcoal comes in a irregular cylindrical shape because our current market is local homes in Nanyuki, Kenya, but as we plan to penetrate the export market and hotel and lodges industry this calls for churning our briquettes in all kind of attractive shapes such as the square, round, goose egg , pillow and so on, to address this we are planning to purchase a state of the art briquettes compressing machine, whose specifications are, Diameter of roller: 360(mm), Motor power: 5.5kw, Capacity KG/H: 800-1000 , PACKAGING SIZE : 1.25*1.25*1.4.

REGISTRATION.

In order to conduct business with hotels and to penetrate the export market in Kenya one has to register his firm as a company, to address this we plan to register our briquettes factory as a company based in Kenya under the name Laikipia EcoVenture and as we expand we also register also in the United States of America.

HOW THE FUNDS WILL BE SPENT.

Briquettes  Compressing Machine T -360 model : $5490

Shipping costs: Qingdao(China)-Mombasa(Kenya) :  $360

Company Registration  and General Administrative costs:$1050

story: On January 22, 2014 we started a campaign of mailing seeds we grew organically to anyone who messaged us their name and mailing address. In the past two years we've mailed seeds to nearly 4000 addresses worldwide. In an effort to continue mailing seeds without the expense we are asking for donations for postage. Thank you for your generosity!

story:
On the morning of Monday, July 2nd, tragedy struck the Yoder household as a fire, started by faulty electrical wiring, destroyed all of the Yoders' belongings. During the fire, they also suffered further devastating tragedy in the loss of their cat, Max. (See article: http://delonline.us/LZlI1h)

The purpose of this fundraiser is to help them to replace their lost belongings. Unfortunately, they did not have renter's insurance to cover the damages, and are now struggling to rebuild their lives. As a donator, you would be helping these two wonderful people.

About Josh and Dani:

Josh and Dani Yoder are two of the most generous, caring and loving people in their wide circle of friends and family. An unbreakable couple for almost a decade, they were joined in marriage in October of 2011, to the great celebration of all of those around them. They have never hesitated to give what they can of themselves to those they love, and are consistently loyal and compassionate. It is our opinion that no one is more deserving of the relief that would be provided in this time of great need.

If you do not know this loving couple, and would still like to give out of the kindness of your heart, know that even the smallest amount would be deserving of deep gratitude; even the cost of a fast food lunch would help them to get their lives back together again and provide them some much-needed relief from this loss.

Thank you for any contribution you might make!

story:
We’re Big Hemp, the company creating a market for Montana-grown hemp.

 

Hemp is a one-of-a-kind natural resource:
It’s sustainable ✅
It’s versatile ✅
It helps fight climate change ✅
It has a high profit margin ✅

However, there are fewer than a dozen hemp facilities in the US, and only two of them treat hemp for things other than CBD oil. And this has stunted the hemp market, despite its approximated $20 billion valuation over the next 5 years.

By backing Big Hemp you’ll help drive demand for a resource responsible for creating a sustainable and innovative industry in Montana.
 

What We Need & What You Get

We need $20,000 to start producing micro-projects to demonstrate the remarkable capabilities of hemp. This year we have our eyes set on:

BIG BETS

+ Launching XL Hemp, the mobile airstream accelerator pushing ideas and awareness for the possibilities and financial opportunities of hemp
+ Seeding a 5-acre hemp field

SMALL BETS

+ Producing Big Hemp branded apparel, stickers, and clothing
+ Partnering with brands to help bring the Big Hemp vision to life
+ An ad campaign to create demand for Montana-grown hemp
+ Funding for the continued development of hemp products
+ Grants for projects that come out of the Montana State University hemp class
+ Hemp seed funding for farmers

Together, we’re building a sustainable industry and bringing more and more innovative hemp solutions to the food, textile, fuel, and construction markets. And when you back Big Hemp you continue to aid Montana’s hemp infrastructure.
 

The Impact

The CBD industry alone is expected to reach more than $20 billion in the next five years. That’s $20 billion for just one part of the hemp plant. The entire plant has more than 25,000 uses ranging from concrete and plastics to bread and clothing to oil and footwear.

Imagine if we grew, processed, and manufactured hemp for more than just CBD oil, the industry would be exponentially more valuable.
 

Risks & Challenges

Today, Montana grows more acres of hemp than anywhere else in the US. And the single barrier between hemp being a natural resource synonymous with sustainability and versatility is infrastructure.

By driving demand for hemp through micro-projects that showcase its capabilities, we can create a market for hemp and bring the industry back to the US.
 

Other Ways You Can Help

Want to do even more for Big Hemp? Spread the word with the help of our media kit, add us on Instagram, and check out our website (wearebighemp.com) for updates.

The entire plant has more than 25,000 uses ranging from concrete and plastics to bread and clothing to oil and footwear.Imagine if we grew, processed, and manufactured hemp for more than just CBD oil, the industry would be exponentially more valuable. Risks & ChallengesToday, Montana grows more acres of hemp than anywhere else in the US. And the single barrier between hemp being a natural resource synonymous with sustainability and versatility is infrastructure.By driving demand for hemp through micro-projects that showcase its capabilities, we can create a market for hemp and bring the industry back to the US. Other Ways You Can HelpWant to do even more for Big Hemp? Spread the word with the help of our media kit, add us on Instagram, and check out our website (wearebighemp.com) for updates.

story:
This campaign is raising funds on behalf of California Trout, a verified nonprofit. All contributions are considered unrestricted gifts and can't be specified for any particular purpose.

THE THREAT:

The Red Flat Nickel Corporation has applied to sink 59 drill holes over 4000 acres on the pristine North Fork of the Smith River. This would pave the way for one of the largest nickel mines in the Western United States. The EPA (Environmental Protection Act) considers hard-rock mining one of the most toxic polluters in the U.S.

For more on the proposed mine read a recent story in the San Francisco Chronicle here (SF Gate).

GOAL:

Keith Brauneis Productions and CalTrout will create a short film about California’s Smith River that will raise awareness of this Wild and Scenic river, its steelhead, its history and its current plight. We will examine current conditions and discuss future threats. 

Once produced, we will submit to relevant film tours such as F3T, IF4, Wild & Scenic Films (having aired with them before), among others, and distribute widely in order to raise awareness of this magnificent, remote river.  To continue to fight off current and future threats, the Smith will need all the support it can get. 

BACK STORY:

The remarkable river with a common name, California's Smith River draws anglers from far away for a chance at its wild salmon and steelhead. Geology and location result in a unique river, draining from the Siskiyou Mountains and the Coast Range. While elsewhere, Northern California's Coast range represents the Franciscan Formation, primarily sandstone, here it more closely aligns with the geology of the Klamath Mountains. Ultramafic rock appears as the oceanic crust collides with the continental crust, resulting in the surface appearance of ancient oceanic serpentine rock.

Steep canyons, combined with heavy rainfall (in some areas, over 200 inches per year), scour these bedrock gorges. The river rises fast, yet recedes just as quickly. Very little sediment is carried by the Smith, resulting in the remarkable jade green and sapphire blues of water so clear, you might be inclined to jump off the drift boat and wade to shore. As one nameless person on our trip discovered, the Big Gulp is a simple step away.

The Smith River has become a poster-child for how, with forward thinking and by dint of hard work, an entire watershed can be protected. Here there are no dams, no wretched clear-cut blocks, no mitigating hatcheries. Instead, ancient forest, including iconic redwood, cloak canyon walls.

The fishery, as a result, is remarkable. Salmon over 60 lbs, and the state record for steelhead, over 27 lbs. Species genetically adapted to heavy fast water, featuring massive caudal fins, or as expert angler Dustin Revel calls their tails, 'giant paddles.' These fish will make you feel under gunned even with a stout rod.

And they're not easy to catch...

YOUR SUPPORT:

Your Tax Deductible Donation is the key to this project's launch and it's inevitable success. The dollars raised in this campaign will go toward the many aspects required for pre-production, filming and post production. But it doesn't stop there.  We'll also get the film in front of as many viewers as possible, raising awareness and creating Smith River fans ready to stand up for its protection against current and future threats.  

RECENT FILM SUCCESS:

Please watch Liquid Gold, story of the Golden Trout and Enough Is Enough, story of the McCloud River. Each film was nationally-aired, was in 2 film tours, and currently reside on more than 10 major websites. Visit Keith Brauneis Productions Outdoor Films for more related films and CalTrout to learn more about restoration efforts.

Risks and challenges 

Every production has inherent risks and challenges, thankfully we have done this many times before and understand the risks involved and how to avoid them, and how to use challenges to our advantage when we can't bypass them. We gathered a small team of seasoned adventurers, ready to face any road blocks.

With our combined years of experience and expertise in all aspects of this production, we feel confident that we will deliver you an outstanding film!
