FOR MORE INFORMATION SEE BELOW:  
VAIGAI RIVER RESTORATION PROJECT DETAILED SUMMARY


What is the Vaigai River Restoration Project?

The Vaigai River Restoration Project is an environmental social action project to mobilize community engagement and implement solutions to restore the Vaigai River and mitigate the severe crisis of water contamination, pollution, waste dumping, and adapt to the drying effects of climate change, affecting the drinking water, agriculture, and the survival of the people of Madurai, South India.




Earth Celebrations’ Hudson River Pageant to restore native species, habitats, and address climate change, New York City. Photo by William Bourassa Jr.
CREATIVE STRATEGIES: Community Building, Public Awareness, Education, Social Action, and Implementation of Solutions

Through the innovative and creative strategy and model of the Vaigai River Restoration Project, we will engage community participants in a grassroots educational and social action campaign. We will utilize community-based art and the theatrical pageant (a procession with site specific performances), an indigenous art-form to mobilize the community to identify the issues, raise public awareness, participate in direct action and implement solutions to mitigate the severe environmental crisis of pollution and contamination of a major natural water resource and to counter the effects of climate change.
An educational workshop series builds community engagement and awareness of the Vaigai River for 3 months from January through April, 2015 leading up to the culminating Vaigai River Restoration Pageant. Through the workshops, environmental educators inspire community participants to learn about the river issues and solutions. This work provides the inspiration and a “place-based” learning process that is foundation for the creative ideas for the pageant. Community participants work with local artisans/artists-in-residence to create giant mobile sculptures, puppets, costumes, visual artwork, and performances to highlight the Vaigai River, its history, habitat, water quality, related issues of sanitation and climate change, and future restoration. The workshops are offered free of cost to the community and culminate in the Vaigai River Restoration Pageant in May 2015.
The culminating Vaigai River Restoration Pageant includes a procession of giant mobile sculptures, spectacular costumes, and musical bands with site-specific performances of theater, music, storytelling, poetry, and dance by local folk performing groups, organizations, schools, and community participants that highlight the issues and solutions of the Vaigai River. 
Location / Procession Route: The performances are presented at significant sites along the banks of the Vaigai River from Villangudi to Albert Victor Bridge and the Maiya Mandapam, in Madurai, Tamil Nadu, South India.

 






Image Source: Nabuur.com











MADURAI 
Madurai, situated on the banks of the Vaigai River, in Tamil Nadu, Southern India, is known as the Temple City of India. Marco Polo called Madurai the most splendid province on Earth. The magnificence of Madurai as a cultural center since the Tamil Era 2,500 years ago, as well as the beauty of the Vaigai River that runs through it, has been celebrated for thousands of years in Indian literature and sacred texts. Here the ancient past exists alongside the modern world, with its people still practicing sacred and ancient traditions rooted in its legendary history. Meenakshi Temple is known for its magnificent Dravidian architecture with gopurams (gateways) completely covered with intricate colorful sculptural images of gods, animals, and mythical creatures. Madurai’s significance as a center for textiles dates back to its ancient past. Madurai is also the place where in 1921 Mahatma Gandhi relinquished his western clothing to wear a loincloth made of khadi (homespun cloth) as an act to align himself with the people, and as an act of social change.

GOALS: Community Building, Social Action, & Solutions
The project plans for the Vaigai River Restoration include the following:
• Raising awareness for better waste management practices among communities.
• Raising awareness for restoration of water quality, efforts to provide safe drinking water, and  DHAN Foundation’s existing projects such as Vayalagam Tankfed Agriculture Development Program (VTADP).
• Building partnerships of stakeholders and engaging city officials, corporations, environmental organizations, activists, farming groups, schools and universities to be mobilized and participate in solutions to restore the river
• Engaging community participation in creative ecological art project and pageant performance to bring attention to the river, its history, and efforts to restore the health of the river for drinking water, agriculture, recreation, and peaceful open space within the city 
• Highlight and initiate proposals for visions for the future of the river such as a river park along the banks of the Vaigai and other recreational uses that promote the care and appreciation of the river, its historical legacy, and future as an ecological oasis within the city





Top: R. Ashok; “And Quietly Flows a Much Sullied Vaigai,” The Hindu, Bottom: R. Ashok; Photo Feature in The Hindu turns PIL Petition, The Hindu 

STATEMENTS
OF NEED 
“Once the preliminary work of clearing garbage is completed, measures will be taken to stop public from letting sewage water into the river. We have invited suggestions from people and activists to keep the river clean.”   - Mayor V.V. Rajan Chellappa of Madurai

“The
major area of pollution falls within the city limit… solid waste, plastic
waste, untreated sewage water from institutions and houses act as the major
pollutants. Only by increasing the water flow of the river, it can be brought
to life again. Mixing of sewage water and dumping of solid waste should also be
stopped to set it right.”   - Professor G
Balaji, Department of Architecture, Thiagarajar College of Engineering
“A
proper vision from all stakeholders will help preserve our rivers.”   - K Kalidas,
President of Osai, an environmental NGO
“Untreated
effluents have raised the pollution level of water. The concentration of total
dissolved solids (TSD) in water here is 3,500 to 4,000 ppm, when the acceptable
level should be below 500 ppm. Resultantly, the areas adjoining Chinnalapatti
are fast becoming barren due to underground pollution. Agriculture is also affected.” - S
Mahendran, Manager of the Agriculture Technology Management Association




Mayor V.V. Rajan Chellappa inspects a mass cleaning program, Vaigai Bed Loses Litter, The Hindu

STRATEGY: Raise Awareness, Mobilize Action &
Implement Solutions

One of the first steps to
restoring the Vaigai River is building a collaborative partnership of
stakeholders, including environmental organizations, schools, universities,
farming groups, activists, government representatives, cultural
institutions, artisans, performers, and the people of Madurai, who
will be mobilized and work together to positively impact the future of the
Vaigai River. Through the innovative and creative strategy, we will
engage community participants in a grassroots educational and social
action campaign. The community will help identify the issues, raise public
awareness, and participate in direct action and implementation of
solutions. 
Actions Already Underway since April 2014: 
• Stakeholders Meetings in Madurai being organized by the DHAN Foundation
• Building partnerships and collaborations for the workshops and pageant
with numerous schools and organizations including TheThiagarajar
College of Engineering, Tata/DHAN Academy, Vivekenanda College, Fatima College, and womens' empowerment groups. The
group of partner organizations and community participants is growing every day,
along with our global support network from New York, California, Delhi, Mumbai,
Chennai, Madurai, and beyond.
• Enlisting artisans of folk art and performing
traditions from clay sculpture, paper mache, handloom weavers, Sungadi sari
makers, artisans utilizing traditional organic vegetable dye techniques,
painters, kavadi headdress builders, as well as performers of music, dance,
theater, poetry, storytelling, and ceremony. 
• Gathering key environmental educators to work
alongside the artisans for the educational workshops.

Earth Celebrations Workshops in 2012 engaging children in NYC to create Stewards of the River Robes using homemade paint made from fruits, vegetables, and plants.
Educational Community-Building Workshops: January — April 2015:
Free workshops will be conducted by the artists-in-residence/workshop instructors in collaboration with environmental educators to engage community members and students, educating the participants
on the issues of the Vaigai River and solutions to be implemented. Asia
Initiatives will bring in their unique system of Social Capital Credits
(SoCCs) as a way to incentivize the community to attend the workshops and
contribute towards the river restoration. The work created in the workshops will
raise awareness for specific issues and will be presented in the Pageant.
The workshop series engages
youth and adults for 3 months to:
•  Explore
the diversity of plant and animal life as indicators of the river’s
health, as well as discuss current issues concerning pollution and waste through
a ‘place-based’ learning process.
•  Work with artists-in-residence to create spectacular
visual arts works such as mobile sculptures/puppets and costumes for the
procession inspired by the species, habitats, issues, and restoration efforts
of the river.
•  Utilize ecologically friendly practices in the
creation of art projects, incorporating the use of recycled, natural and
organic materials.
•  Engage local artisans to participate in the project creating visual art projects highlighting their folk art traditions such as: clay sculptures, costumes, handloom textiles, bamboo/paper-maché sculpture, decorative processional staffs, headdresses, masks, face painting,
palanquins/processional sculpture carts, kolam rice/chalk powder drawings,
Sungudi saree and dyeing techniques, that revive traditional vegetables dyes
rather than chemical dyes that pollute the river.
•  Social Capital Credits (SoCCs), a virtual currency for social good, will be used to implement the above processes not only during the workshops, but as a long term practice for sustainable ecological and social development. People will be able to earn SoCCs by helping with the pageant, and river cleaning actions such as waste management, maintaining irrigation channels and water tanks, planting trees etc. They will be able to use the SoCCs thus earned to get services like subsidized electricity, telephone talk time, school scholarships, healthcare, etc. 
(CLICK HERE TO LEARN HOW SoCCs WILL HELP IN VAIGAI RIVER RESTORATION)
•  Develop solutions for river restoration.





Image Sources Starting from Top: K. Ananthan, The Hindu; Earth Celebrations Hudson River Pageant Puppet Workshop, New York City; S. James, The Hindu

VAIGAI
RIVER RESTORATION PAGEANT:Procession
with Site-Specific Performances: April 2015 
The educational
community-building workshop series is planned to culminate in the Vaigai River
Pageant. The pageant will feature a procession of giant mobile sculptures,
spectacular costumes, and musical bands highlighting the Vaigai River. 
Performances by local artists and community groups will be presented at
significant sites along the route, following the river bank in Madurai.  Performances will include theater, dance,
songs, music, poetry, and ceremony highlighting the history, current issues,
and future restoration of the river. 

Mulaipari festival at
Koovathupatti, Tamil Nadu,  HenkOochappan, TrekEarth 

 Visual Art and Performances for the Pageant:   
• Giant mobile sculptures on traditional processional carts and puppets utilize local folk traditions to represent native species, habitat, history, issues, and efforts to restore the
river. 
• Costumes will utilize folk traditions and incorporate handloom textiles and Sungudi fabrics, a traditional craft of Madurai. Craftsmen will be incentivized to use traditional vegetable dyes rather than chemical pigments that pollute the river. 
• Educational performances by local performing and community groups address: legacy of Vaigai River in mythological and historic texts; native river species and habitats; issues of waste and sewage dumping; industrial and chemical pollution; and restoration efforts to improve water quality, water flow, and health of the river.    
• Organic Planting Performance celebrating the river as a life source for agriculture and sustainable organic farming and importance of water storage tank restoration for irrigation.
• River Cleansing Ceremony will engage community participants in
a choreographed movement and clean-up along the river bank. 
• Live Fish Release: ceremonial action - children offer fish
back to the river.
Pageant Date: May 2015: Prior to Chithirai Festival in Madurai, Tamil Nadu, South India



Top: Mulaipari festival at Koovathupatti, Tamil Nadu; Terres de Charme,Middle: Young students performing
traditional dances, Lokvani, Bottom: Men in procession carrying large
decorative ambala kalvadis, The Hindu


WHO WE ARE
FOUNDING CO-SPONSORS –The Vaigai River Restoration Project is produced by Earth Celebrations, a non-profit environmental and arts organization based in New York City, in partnership with the DAHN Foundation, an NGO and non-profit organization working to restore the Vaigai River in Madurai, South India.
Earth Celebrations– Earth
Celebrations is a New York City based non-profit organization founded by
Felicia Young which works to engage communities to address and effect change on ecological issues through the arts. Earth Celebrations’ creative environmental and arts programs address and effect change on issues such as:  climate change, river species and habitat restoration, and the preservation of community gardens, parks, and a healthy urban environment, while highlighting ecological sustainability. Earth Celebrations’ innovative theatrical pageants and community-based arts programs address crucial ecological issues, including our 15 year effort that led to the preservation of community gardens on the Lower East Side and throughout New York City and the Hudson River Pageant to raise awareness for the restoration of the Hudson River and addressing climate change.  
Earth Celebrations
Past Sponsors include:
World Financial Center, Brookfield
Properties, Bank of America, Con
Edison, Citibank, Chase Bank,
Colgate-Palmolive, Eileen Fisher,
New York State Council on the Arts,
Lower Manhattan Cultural Council
and The Hudson River Park Trust. 
earthcelebrations.com

DHAN
Foundation– Development
of Humane Action (DHAN) Foundation, an NGO and nonprofit organization based in Madurai, South India, has a mission to “build people and institutions for
development innovations and upscale (them) to enable poverty reduction and
self-reliance in poor communities.” The program has identified ‘water’ as a unique tool for alleviating poverty and has evolved into a separate people’s institution, the ‘DHAN Vayalagam (Tank) Foundation (DVTF)’. The Foundation aims to restore water quality and access water through tank-based watershed development supporting agriculture needs. DHAN is also engaged in programs to clean and restore the Vaigai River from waste dumping and contaminants, and to raise community awareness and participation in these efforts. DHAN (Development of Human Action) Foundation, was awarded the India
NGO award in 2009 by The Rockefeller Foundation.
DHAN Foundation Sponsors include: Ford Foundation, Sir Rata Tata Trust, Axis Bank
Foundation, International Water Management Institute-RUAF Foundation and the Department of Tourism, Tamil Nadu. dhan.org

Asia Initiatives– Asia Initiatives (AI), a New York registered non-profit organization undertakes projects that are pro-environment and pro-poor. AI has pioneered the use of Social Capital Credits (SoCCs) to incentivize local people to undertake social good activities, and will develop the SoCCs system to incentivize attendance in the workshops, and the restoration the Vaigai River, working closely with the local community and other stakeholders. This initiative is leadby Dr. Geeta Mehta, Professor of Architecture and Urban Design at Columbia University and the Founder/President of Asia Initiatives. 
Asia Initiatives Corporate Partners include: Aveda, Japan Citigroup Services
(Japan) Ltd., Credit Suisse, First Boston Securities, Daimler Chrysler, and Ford Motor Company to name a few. asiainitiatives.org


PROJECT LEADERSHIP
Felicia Young, Co-Founder/Co-Director
is a theatrical pageant director and founder of Earth Celebrations a non-profit
organization dedicated to engaging communities to address and effect change on
ecological issues through the arts. She has produced large-scale theatrical
pageants for the past 25 years such as the Rites of Spring: Procession to Save
Our Gardens (1991-2005) on the Lower East Side of New York City, which
mobilized a grass-root effort and directly led to the preservation of many
community gardens on the Lower East Side and throughout New York City. In 2009
Felicia launched the Hudson River Pageant to restore the species and habitats
of the Hudson River and address climate change in New York City. She has
produced and directed theatrical pageants and community-based arts projects for
numerous organizations including: the New York City Department of Parks and
Recreation, the Alternative Museum, Lincoln Center for The Performing Arts,
Lower Manhattan Cultural Council, Brookfield Properties> arts World
Financial Center, The World Trade Center, and Earth Day New York. She has a BA
in Art History from Skidmore College, 1987, and a MA degree in Performance
Studies from New York University, 1994. earthcelebrations.com
Rajasekaran
Jesudasan, Co-Founder is
a Trustee of Arunachalam Jesudasan Trust and Field Director CM Centre Madurai
Services for International Scholars, Educators, Researchers & Students in
South India, where he is currently on a sabbatical for a year until May 2015.
He served for more than 25 years as Resident Coordinator for the University of
Wisconsin’s College Year in India Programme, Madurai, and during that time also
assisted a great many visiting scholars from USA and European Universities. As
Field Director at CM Centre, Sekar organizes every resource necessary to
provide for the needs of scholars and students, ranging from setting up
meetings with government agencies, NGOs, individuals, private institutions or business
houses to interviewing a village shaman. For the past 20 years Sekar has been
researching and documenting the Vaigai River and is Co-Author of Stretch of
Life on the Vaigai River with Peter Nabakov. Rajasekaran as Co-Director of
the Vaigai River Restoration Pageant Project will coordinate with DHAN
Foundation and Earth Celebrations, engage collaborating community partners,
artists, and performers, and manage production logistics. Sekar is also a
social activist and a musician who performs throughout Tamil Nadu, including
the Hard Rock Cafe in Madras. He has a B.A. degree in English Literature from
American College in Madurai . cmcentre.org
Dr. M.P. Vasimalai,
Phd, Co-Founder/Co-Sponsor is the
Founder/ Executive Director of the DHAN Foundation in India. Mr. M.P.
Vasimalai, Executive Director of DHAN Foundation is a post graduate in
Agriculture and a management graduate from the Indian Institute of Management,
Ahmedabad. He has over three decades of experience in development work and is one
of the key people in setting up Professional Assistance for Development Action
(PRADAN). He was instrumental in setting up DHAN Foundation in 1997. He has
specialized in community organization, designing development interventions in
the fields of natural resource management, livelihood promotion and
institutional development. He has traveled extensively within and outside India
and has presented papers on these themes. He is also holding various positions
in national and international forums, working groups, task forces and missions
of Central and State governments on these themes. He was instrumental in promoting
various network organizations. His areas of interest are institution building,
leadership development and promoting various development themes for poverty
reduction.
P. Vasunathan,  Vaigai Restoration Project Coordinator, DHAN Foundation
Dr. David Blake
Willis, PhD, Project Advisor, Professor of Anthropology, Fielding Graduate University, Santa
Barbara, USA Doctoral faculty – School of Human & Organizational
Development.  Lived and worked in Madurai, South India, and lived 35 years
in Asia, including Kobe, Japan, where rivers are a prime cultural/ecological
feature of the landscape. 
Dr. Geeta Mehta, PhD, Project Co-Sponsor, Founder/President
of Asia Initiatives.
Geeta is the Adjunct Professor of Architecture and Urban Design at Columbia
University in New York.  She serves on
the advisory board of Millennium Cities Initiatives at the Earth Institute at
Columbia University. She has worked on community focused design and poverty
alleviation projects in India, Ghana, Kenya, Jamaica, Brazil, and Colombia. She
is also the Co-Founder of “URBZ: User Generated Cities” (www.urbz.net), a think tank committed to empowering people at the
community level to improve their own neighborhoods. Geeta is the past President
of the American Institute of Architects’ Japan Chapter. asiainitiatives.org
We also invite others throughout the world who
appreciate the Vaigai River and its deep history around Madurai to join us.
FUNDING
At this point we need funding to make this project possible. Our campaign is here specifically to fund our Educational Community-Building Workshop Series that is part of the Vaigai River Restoration Pageant Project.
The Future of the Vaigai River
With your support, the Vaigai River will be renewed with creative inspiration and collaborative efforts of the community as well as the support of the many individuals and organizations in Madurai and beyond who care about the future of the rivers, natural resources, ecological sustainability, and water on which we all depend for our future survival.

story:
AN URGENT APPEAL TO ALL ANTI-FRACKING FRIENDS
Imagine a small rural village in a peaceful part of North Nottinghamshire. Next to a site of Special Scientific Interest there is a wonderful nature reserve. Soon the
birds will be frightened away by 24 hour a day drilling. We expect IGas to put in a formal application to Notts County Council in May. This will be to drill an
exploratory well and do some deep experimental fracking into the Bowland Shale. The intention is to crack open the rocks with hundreds of gallons of water and
poisons. They want to draw up methane which will damage the environment. A short space away is an aquifer which is made of special sandstone and supplies pure drinking water across the north of the county. The fracking company have spent thousands of pounds already on glossy exhibitions to try and convince the
villagers that everything will be fine. Those who know anything about the real dangers of fracking know that it will not.

That is why we are appealing to you. We have a small band of volunteers playing David against Goliath. We have only little money left for leaflets. We do not
have a real income from anywhere.

But now we have a chance to defeat the fracking company. There is a retired professor of geology, who is now living in a French village and is passionately
against fracking. He has told the Chairman of the Bassetlaw Against Fracking group that he is very concerned about damage and leakage into the water supply. If
he can prove this, his evidence will be significant in persuading the Notts County Council Planning Committee not to agree to the application.

He is Emeritus Professor David Smythe. His lifetime work in studying geology was at Glasgow University. Already he has helped anti-fracking groups in Scotland,
Lancashire and the village of Balcombe in the south of England with his research he has agreed to help us. However to produce a 40 to 50 page report and to come
over to a Planning committee meeting to present it will cost money. He is a pensioner now, but very alert to the dangers. So a report which would normally cost
£16,000 from a commercial firm, he will do for £1500 plus £300 for his return fare.

If everyone who reads this appeal in the anti-fracking community provided us with just £2 we feel sure we could meet the target of £1800 that is needed.

PLEASE HELP US AS SOON AS YOU CAN. THANK YOU.
David Larder. (Chair of Bassetlaw against Fracking)

story:
Keep Inside Green Growing EVEN MORE!!

You have inspired us! Inside Green is now hoping to raise up to $10,000 in an effort to get matching funds from the City of Vancouver. Learn more in our latest update!

 

For EVERY $1000 WE RAISE we can:

  • Buy 80 more plants
  • Or visit 2 more classrooms
  • Or run a booth for 1 day at a farmer’s market
  • Or add more functionality to the website
  • Or whatever you want to do based on the perks you choose!

Together we can do more! Please keep spreading the word and contributing what you can.

Let’s green even more of the city from the inside out!
 

The Big Picture

Sue Biely was worried about the planet and wasn't sure what she could do about it. Living in Vancouver and working in the culture sector, she has the heart of an activist and the skills of a storyteller, educator, and group facilitator. One day, in her apartment high off the ground in a city that gets more densely populated and urbanized every year, she found herself wondering "what would this city look like in ten years if our homes and offices had no indoor plants?

When we live in spaces that are all right-angles and man-made materials, what does that do to our brains? What is happening to our ancient knowledge of how to take care of plants, how to make plant babies, and what different plants are good for? What if our connection to nature also impacts our connection to each other?

Inside Green seeks to play with these questions and more. What if we were to gift every urbanite an indoor plant? What if we each had a little piece of nature brought into our homes or workspaces...that we were personally responsible for? What if those of us who live in boxes in the sky, who don’t have access to soil, could actually feel what it is like to connect with a piece of living nature, and to steward it?

Sue decided to experiment. 

The result is Inside Green, a project that gifts plants to urbanites and teaches them how to care for those plants and propagate them, in turn gifting those baby plants to the community around them.

This project removes waste from the waste cycle by re-using cans, increases individuals’ access to nature, and greens the inside of buildings. It produces cleaner air for the city, and provides numerous health benefits for those who share space with indoor plants. Plant gifting connects Vancouverites with each other, and provides a gentle introduction to stewardship. Inside Green's website tracks the data and collects stories about how Vancouverites are growing a greener city.

We have already been hard at work on a pilot project, and are ready to take this *BIGGER*. Our goal is to gift more plants in the Vancouver area, build more social interaction features on the website, and lead more educational workshops in schools and businesses about indoor plants. We wish to deepen the elements and experience of community (and FUN!), while showing evidence of how this is a thriving, successful method of greening our cities from the inside out.

We believe in the power of positive change, one small action at a time, through the simplicity of indoor plants and building connections with the people around us.

Our History, and our Future

Inside Green was piloted in the summer of 2016 thanks to a grant from Creative BC’s Interactive Fund and the involvement and support of many friends and community activists. There are over 650 plants registered on the Inside Green website, with 25% of those being plant babies from the original gifted plants. We have shown up at farmer's markets and thrown "plant parties" where we have given out plants to everyone that was interested and willing to register as a Plant Steward on our website. We have created a Plantcestry on our site to track where plant babies go and who they have come from, so as to better see the spreading GREENeology of plants and community across our city. We have created videos that show step by step ‘how to make plant babies’ with all the different species of plants we have been gifting. We have collected video footage of school groups learning about indoor plants, and students receiving their own plants to take home, nurture, and love. We have received incredible stories of plants that have accompanied humans through various life experiences - sometimes spanning generations and thousands of miles. We have tapped into a vein, and want to take this adventure FURTHER.

The potential of this plant-gifting project to go viral is huge, and the beneficiaries will be ALL OF US. The more we are able to demonstrate with data and stories the positive impact of greening our cities from the inside out,  the more momentum we can create.  One plant, one person at a time we hope to model and inspire collective stewardship that will shift our relationship to the planet. And so we hope to not only green Vancouver, but to green any city that is growing vertically around the world!

Inside Green has been created with a structure that is ready for expansion: we are ready to grow as funds allow. More green! Healthier people! Cleaner air! Preservation of our knowledge of propagation and how to successfully steward nature's growth! Let's shift our concept of nature from being "out there" and “someone else's responsibility,” to being in our living spaces and directly connected to mutual health and well-being!

No, Really, Indoor Plants are SO Good for Us!

The research is really quite impressive on the significant impact indoor plants have on us and the environment around them. Our sources are below, feel free to check our research out for yourself!

Boost your emotional, physical and mental health with plants!
Indoor plants have been shown to have a significant impact on the general well-being of people. Research has demonstrated their ability to:

  • Boost mood, increasing happiness
  • Improve relationships and access to feeling compassion 
  • Reduce stress
  • Lower blood pressure
  • Improve concentration and memory retention
  • Increase accuracy
  • Decrease reaction time
  • Calm minds and reduce fatigue
  • Support better, deeper sleep
  • Increase productivity
  • Relieve aches and pains
  • Accelerate the healing process
  • Decrease the number of sick days taken from work

Plants want to help clean your space from toxins and irritants!
Indoor plants interact with the air they are in better than filters or fans. Here’s what plants do for the environment inside:

  • Purify and revitalize stale air
  • Reduce airborne contaminants such as mold spores, dust, and bacteria, (plants have been found to reduce the airborne content by as much as 50-60%!)
  • Regulate the humidity of a room, keeping it at the optimum level for human comfort, health and productivity
  • Increase ozone, and reduce pollutants (smog) and chemicals such as formaldehyde, benzene, trichloroethylene, acetone and nitrogen
  • Lower the temperature on hot days, with greater efficiency than air conditioners
  • Lower background noise (reducing noise pollution from outside, and providing a buffer for noise created inside)

The Science:

1 Lohr, V.I., C.H. Pearson-Mims, and G.K. Goodwin. 1996. Interior plants may improve worker productivity and reduce stress in a windowless environment.  J. of Environmental Horticulture 14(2):97-100. 

2 Kobayashi, Kaufman, Griffis, and McConnell. 2007. Using Houseplants To Clean Indoor Air http://www.ctahr.hawaii.edu/oc/freepubs/pdf/of-39.pdf

3 http://www.ambius.com/learn/benefits-of-our-services/index.html

4 http://www.mydomaine.com/best-indoor-plants-for-clean-air/

5 http://www.plantcultureinc.com/whyGreen.html

6 http://smallspaces.about.com/od/Tiny-Houses/ss/11-Houseplants-Ideas-That-Outsmart-the-Winter-Blahs.htm

7 http://ellisonchair.tamu.edu/health-and-well-being-benefits-of-plants

Many research studies can be found here:

http://greenplantsforgreenbuildings.org/
 

The Theory Behind the Design

    How do we successfully foster change and create true measurable positive impact on the environment? This question was the guiding force behind the design of Inside Green. 

    If our goal is to have more people engage in new plant-stewardship behaviours - successfully, and long-term - then we need to make it easy for them. This means reducing risk and failure, making it easy to sign up and receive a plant, and creating intrinsic rewards that make people feel awesome as they try on a new habit. 

    To this end, we have made the process the playful, matching people with plants through a fun interactive tool, celebrating key points in the plants progress with Stewards, and setting the expectation that this is a no-shame project: if your plant dies, it’s simply to be marked as compost.

    We create accountability through gentle means: by gifting plants through real-life relationships, we naturally access motivation and encouragement. Renewed interactions with family, friends, and neighbours around baby plants creates new community bonds, a happy side-effect that we are delighted to support. Watching how your plant connects you to the community at large as plants have babies and are gifted forward is an empowering visual reminder of the impact we have on our community and environment through the simple act of stewardship of indoor plants.

    Most environmental projects seek to change our behaviour by encouraging us to do something less and give things up. Inside Green inverts that by providing a positive tangible experience with a real slice of nature - a pleasant addition to participants’ lives rather than one more thing they need to stop or remove for the sake of environmental sustainability.

    We also went one step farther by pulling materials from the waste cycle as much as possible. Our plants are placed in aluminum can "pots" - every can was originally destined for either recycling or the landfill, and we have reclaimed them and repurposed them as housing for our indoor plant babies.

    What Could go Wrong?

    We've worked out most of the kinks already with our prototype and pilot program that launched in 2016. So here's what could possibly throw a wrench in our plans: all the plants die (which would mean we make a heap of really good compost); we can't get enough 28 fl oz cans out of the waste cycle and need to find something else to use as pots; or sign-ups to become stewards are slowed by hindrances such as: the majority of our urbanites have already lost the ability to care for plants and are unwilling to re-learn, people think that looking after nature is something that someone else does, a lack of interest in having plants inside their home.

    We have already witnessed a response to the project that indicates we will not encounter these problems (at least, not enough to cause significant hampering of our goals). When it comes to any potential large-scale plant death scenarios, we have Brian Minter of the famous Minter Gardens advising us - which should keep our plants hale and hearty.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you live in the Vancouver area, becoming a "can collector" for us would be AMAZING! We can use all the 28 fl oz cans (such as large cans of diced tomatoes or beans) we can get! 

    Do you know of a business or an organization that would be interested in sponsoring plants to come into their office or a school? Would you be willing to talk us up and get the door opened for us? That would be terrific!

    Would you be willing to spread the word? We've received so much positive feedback, and every new person who hears about our project is a new potential plant steward or plant donor. One by one, we are growing our presence. We'd be so honoured if you would pass our message forward!

    https://insidegreen.ca/
story_txt:
Keep Inside Green Growing EVEN MORE!!
You have inspired us! Inside Green is now hoping to raise up to $10,000 in an effort to get matching funds from the City of Vancouver. Learn more in our latest update!

 
For EVERY $1000 WE RAISE we can:

Buy 80 more plants

Or visit 2 more classrooms

Or run a booth for 1 day at a farmer’s market

Or add more functionality to the website

Or whatever you want to do based on the perks you choose!

Together we can do more! Please keep spreading the word and contributing what you can.

story:
Plastic Energy Solutions

Owner: Karl Klaiss

PES is a company that was founded for one reason:

To help clean up the planet one step at a time.

However we found that cleaning up the mess was only half the problem. After a short while the mess would reappear due to human consumption. So rather than try to clean up the mess on the ground, we decided to start the cleanup process at or before the dumpster. 

After being in manufacturing for nearly 20 years with almost half of that dedicated to plastics, I found that much of the plastic we use and throw away today could be a potential source of energy in one form or another if converted properly. The problem was that the recycling methods used in many places today combined the plastics into a single pile from which many recyclers would have to employ specific sorting methods to separate what they deemed of value versus the rest of the waste.


<><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><>

The tech behind the process:

Using current technology PES employs Pyrolysis, a recycling method that will convert plastic back into usable oil. Though there are several types of pyrolysis operations in the U.S., the basic problem with many of these units is that they are geared specifically for only one type of plastic. In the PES process, we are able to employ a combination of technologies to convert four of the seven plastic varieties into oil.

The plastics able to be converted by the PES process:

#2 - HDPE

#4 - LDPE

#5 - PP

#6 - PS

<><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><>

The Goal:

With the desktop model up and running, we will be looking to build a processing center that will be able to convert approximately 1,300 lbs. of material per day into oil. However, our stretch goal would be to employ not just one but several machines to recycle more of the waste produced every day. For every ton of plastic that we recycle we save:

  • 30 cubic yards of landfill space.
  • 5,774 kWh of electricity.
  • 685 gallons of oil.
  • 98 million BTU's of energy.

Considering that just one of our machines recycles 1,300 lbs. per day that will equate to almost 170 tons of material that will never reach the landfill each year. 

Employment Goal:

In most recycling businesses the inevitable job of sorting is handled by automation where possible and able workers where it is not. At PES our focus is not on automation but rather the people and we plan to hire underprivileged and disabled individuals. To us this is the best way we can serve the community and the people within it. 

<><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><>

The Funding:

The funds raised from this campaign will be used for:

  • Tooling for production machine.
  • Oil tank.
  • Solar panel installation.
  • Website components.
  • Donator perks.
  • Operating costs.

<><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><>

Now to the perks:

First and foremost, we will be starting a daily blog on our website that will update continuously on the amount of waste we will be removing from the environment. This will be the way that each contributor can view the total impact on the environment from their donations.

$1 - Thanks you. Thank you. Thank you. Really, we cannot thank you enough. We will place your name on our website as a contributor to our cause. 

$45 - This gets you a sports bottle made out of our favorite material - recycled plastics and a spot on our website contributor page. Please keep in  mind that when the bottle wears out please send it back to us. We will process it just way we do the rest of the plastics. But make sure you get your use out of it first.


$70 - This gets you a sports bottle made out of our favorite material - recycled plastics and a spot on our website contributor page.

$250 - T-shirt with our company logo on the front and the Architect quote from R. Buckminster Fuller on the back plus a spot on our contributor page.

$500 - Sweatshirt with our company logo on the front and the Architect quote from R. Buckminster Fuller plus a spot on our contributor page.

$1,000 - Gets you an engraved placque and a t-shirt for your family of 4 that has the logo on the front and the Architect quote from R. Buckminster Fuller plus a spot on our contributor page.

$5,000 and up - Contact us so we can discuss as I do not know how to say thank you that much by myself so we will put our heads together to come up with something just for you. 

<><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><>

The Impact

Plastic recycling is not just about the ability to help clean up the environment, but it also helps to take us to that next level in building a sustainable society. What we do today has repercussions for the future so if we each provide a small effort now, the repercussion will be evident tomorrow. In the gallery you will find a small file with a snippet of the impact that waste has just from a collection view. 

How is Pyrolysis deployed by PES able to be used on different plastics vs other companies using the same tech?

PES uses a technology that enables the complete mixture of #2, 4, 5, & 6 prior to the melt stage. During the pyrolysis process the plastic is then heated to eventually turn the solid into a gas form. This gas is then liquefied through a condensation of the gas and the off gases are separated and channeled to a catalytic converter (similar to that of a car) and release as water vapor and CO2. The main difference from other companies is that they use the off gasses to run their combustion generators thus in the end they are still adding to the pollutants such as CO and other combustion pollutants into the atmosphere. 

The oil produced, by these different plastics, will it be used differently?

Typically most companies that utilize pyrolysis attack the higher commodity cost goods in the waste stream such as tires and other very specific plastics such as strictly #6 plastic. These goods produce an oil that is in demand by specific industries so they set up their production based on that single stream function. 

At PES we look at the stream from a vantage point that it is all waste and it all needs to be cleaned up, not just the single type. The heating oil produced is a higher grade then typically sold on the open market because of its sulfur free content but because it is cheaper to produce than processing through crude we will be able to offer the finished product to dealers and distributors cheaper than the oil companies. 

Additionally, since the finished oil product is free of sulfur it burns cleaner then its counterparts sold by the oil companies. This is partly due to the regulations for home heating oil are lesser than other crude oil byproducts. When looking at home heating furnaces the efficiency ratings are considerably higher than the diesel engine (which by the way #2 oil and diesel are the same thing). 

The reason that PES will not be pushing into the diesel market is due to regulations surrounding the sulfur requirements and the fact that we do not look to add to that side of the pollution equation. However, I did get one argument from a group of people that I spoke with about the fact that we are still producing oil to burn. The fact of that is true but when you compare the diesel engine efficiency of 40 - 50% to that of a home heating unit between 80 - 95% we all begin to see the difference. 

<><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><>

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand if you cannot contribute but we ask that you pass the word so that more people hear about our ideas. You can use Facebook, Twitter, email, blogs,  the old fashion word of mouth and the Indiegogo tools below the video.

$1 - Thanks you. Thank you. Thank you. Really, we cannot thank you enough. We will place your name on our website as a contributor to our cause. $45 - This gets you a sports bottle made out of our favorite material - recycled plastics and a spot on our website contributor page. Please keep in  mind that when the bottle wears out please send it back to us. We will process it just way we do the rest of the plastics. But make sure you get your use out of it first.$70 - This gets you a sports bottle made out of our favorite material - recycled plastics and a spot on our website contributor page. $250 - T-shirt with our company logo on the front and the Architect quote from R. Buckminster Fuller on the back plus a spot on our contributor page. $500 - Sweatshirt with our company logo on the front and the Architect quote from R. Buckminster Fuller plus a spot on our contributor page. $1,000 - Gets you an engraved placque and a t-shirt for your family of 4 that has the logo on the front and the Architect quote from R. Buckminster Fuller plus a spot on our contributor page.$5,000 and up - Contact us so we can discuss as I do not know how to say thank you that much by myself so we will put our heads together to come up with something just for you.  <><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><>




The Impact
Plastic recycling is not just about the ability to help clean up the environment, but it also helps to take us to that next level in building a sustainable society. What we do today has repercussions for the future so if we each provide a small effort now, the repercussion will be evident tomorrow. In the gallery you will find a small file with a snippet of the impact that waste has just from a collection view. 

How is Pyrolysis deployed by PES able to be used on different plastics vs other companies using the same tech?
PES uses a technology that enables the complete mixture of #2, 4, 5, & 6 prior to the melt stage. During the pyrolysis process the plastic is then heated to eventually turn the solid into a gas form. This gas is then liquefied through a condensation of the gas and the off gases are separated and channeled to a catalytic converter (similar to that of a car) and release as water vapor and CO2. The main difference from other companies is that they use the off gasses to run their combustion generators thus in the end they are still adding to the pollutants such as CO and other combustion pollutants into the atmosphere. 
The oil produced, by these different plastics, will it be used differently?
Typically most companies that utilize pyrolysis attack the higher commodity cost goods in the waste stream such as tires and other very specific plastics such as strictly #6 plastic. These goods produce an oil that is in demand by specific industries so they set up their production based on that single stream function. 
At PES we look at the stream from a vantage point that it is all waste and it all needs to be cleaned up, not just the single type. The heating oil produced is a higher grade then typically sold on the open market because of its sulfur free content but because it is cheaper to produce than processing through crude we will be able to offer the finished product to dealers and distributors cheaper than the oil companies. 
Additionally, since the finished oil product is free of sulfur it burns cleaner then its counterparts sold by the oil companies. This is partly due to the regulations for home heating oil are lesser than other crude oil byproducts. When looking at home heating furnaces the efficiency ratings are considerably higher than the diesel engine (which by the way #2 oil and diesel are the same thing). 
The reason that PES will not be pushing into the diesel market is due to regulations surrounding the sulfur requirements and the fact that we do not look to add to that side of the pollution equation. However, I did get one argument from a group of people that I spoke with about the fact that we are still producing oil to burn. The fact of that is true but when you compare the diesel engine efficiency of 40 - 50% to that of a home heating unit between 80 - 95% we all begin to see the difference. 

<><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><><>


Other Ways You Can Help
We understand if you cannot contribute but we ask that you pass the word so that more people hear about our ideas. You can use Facebook, Twitter, email, blogs,  the old fashion word of mouth and the Indiegogo tools below the video.

story:
Summary

On April 25, 2015, a massive earthquake of 7.8 magnitude struck Nepal causing widespread destruction. Three days and some 80 aftershocks later, with rising death toll of more than five thousand,  people in rural Nepal are now feeling the brunt of the catastrophe. At least 8 million- one third of the entire Nepali population have been affected.

As the international relief efforts and funds come together, smaller modular projects with specific goal become more important. With this in mind, Team Nidan and ADWAN, who in past have a history of extensive social and economical work in the area, are putting together an immediate food and shelter relief fund for three villages of Gorkha District - Bakrang, Taklung and Tanglichok. These villages, although only about eighty kilometers outside of Kathmandu, are nestled within treacherous hills and mountains and are some of the most inaccessible areas of the country.   

Nidan has worked and funded projects in Nepal since 2012 and are continuously working with local NGO - ADWAN Gorkha district. Our combined team of doctors, nurses and social workers was there last month (March 2015) for Reproductive and Child Health Education. You can see their work at - 

  • With GHETS - Our International US based partner - http://www.ghets.org/projects/a-community-clinic-in-nepal/
  • With ADWAN - Our Nepal based fellow NGO - https://www.globalgiving.org/donate/14728/empower-dalit-women-of-nepal/info/
  • Our Home page - Nidan - http://nidan.org.np/

We are currently working to get accurate information from Kathmandu, the capital and outside the capital where resources are even more bleak. We will be partnering with vetted organizations and institutions to support not just the immediate efforts but also the intermediate and long term effects of this disaster. 

The Impact

Initial information from the villages and community have dismal reports. There is pressing need for food, shelter, sanitation and safety. We are planning to help raise some of the initial amount needed by ADWAN and the local community leaders to provide these basic necessities of the impoverished and now devastated population of the area. All the money raised (beside the processing fees) will be donated to local organizations on the ground in Nepal.

We encourage you all to donate some money, even a dollar is worth Nepali rupees 100, enough to feed one person for an entire day.

The money raised will be used for - 

  • Basic Food and Water supply for the rural villages of Bakrang, Taklung and Tanglichok.
  • Transportation of food and water to these areas.
  • Temporary Shelter for the affected community.

News and References about Earthquake

  • Why we don't recommend volunteering at this time: http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2015/apr/27/earthquake-nepal-dont-rush-help-volunteers-aid?CMP=fb_gu
  • List of credible organizations to make donations to: http://www.nytimes.com/2015/04/27/world/asia/where-to-donate-for-nepal.html
  • The destruction at Everest: http://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-32483119
  • A Nepali journalist talks about disaster preparedness: http://www.cnn.com/videos/world/2015/04/27/intv-amanpour-nepal-kunda-dixit.cnn

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • If you feel you want to donate directly to other organizations and fundraisers here are the links we recommend.
  1. Indiegogo - Nepal Earthquake Relief Fund - https://life.indiegogo.com/fundraisers/nepal-earthquake-relief-fund/x/1065116
  2. GlobalGiving Foundation - Nepal Earthquake Relief Fund http://www.globalgiving.org/projects/nepal-earthquake-relief-fund/
Again, we thank you for your generosity and promise regular updates and transparency in this process.

Prashant Khatiwada, Aditi Giri, Prasana Khatiwoda
General Physicians (from Nepal) (www.nidan.org.np)
Helping our partner organization - ADWAN Nepal - for Rescue and Relief Efforts

story:
the not so

Short Summary

I want to start this off by saying. Even If I am unable to raise another dime here. I want to thank you for reading, And say that if you weren't aware of the tiny house movement, you should be, Its neat. And while it is NOT for everybody, It might just be for you :)

Now, a bit about me. *This was written at different times, as I'm a bit of an oddball with afterthoughts. *

I work and work, Its really all I know how to do. I work just to go home, just to go to work. Which you know I'm fine with. What I'm not fine with however is doing all of this just to pay someone else s mortgage. Rent is a black hole, and I'm tired of being stretched out to my singularity trying to pay it. I watched a documentary that introduced and idea that I am stunned I haven't thought of, and that is one of building a tiny house..

I'd love to tell a whole story about myself, and make it easier to connect with me. But the last thing I want is for this to be some kind of sob story.  Which most of my life has been, But that is not the point I want to get across, or why I'm hoping you would help. I just want to be free of the rising living cost in a city I am unable to move away from.  In the current state of affairs I am in, I wont be able to save enough for 14 years ( rough calculations based on current bills, no raise, and a assumed income ) . . Now you can see why I turned here. It didn't used to be this bad , before my room mate moved out with 0 notice a few months back. Did I mention he was the lease holder , and I'm paying rent as a squatter essentially? I am however repainting the house and trying to leave it nicer than when we moved in. I do my best with what I got. I want something of my own though. I cant bring myself to sign another lease, with another room mate. Not again.

I quit drinking last year, and smoking in Feb. of this year. Mainly to save money, but also for my health. I use E-cigs, which I build myself, simply because it is the cheapest option. I fix my 1994 Mazda truck myself ( Paid $500 for it 3 years back ). I feel like I must add these details for my frugality has been called into question.  To that I welcome anyone to visit me for a week. Bring Your Own Food.


My plan is to get a trailer and build the shell as fast as possible, then live in it while I finish it. I cannot afford however to buy the trailer and pay my rent at the same time. I struggle just to get my rent paid each month.. I want to be clear, I dont want people to pay for me to build my own house. More just help me get the first peice, The trailer. From there I can afford the whole project. There is just outright no way I can lump $5k for a trailer.. So if helping a stranger free himself sounds like something your interested in. Feel free, and thank you from the bottom of my heart if you have even taken the time to read this. Tiny houses might be for you as well :)

TL:DR: Cant afford a trailer to start construction of my a tiny house. Giving this a go
:) If anyone has any suggestions, or questions. I'm new to this so feel free to ask .

story:
Who are we? What do we do?

Wisdom of the Elders, Inc. records and preserves oral history, cultural arts, language concepts, and traditional ecological knowledge of exemplary American Indian cultural leaders, historians, and environmentalists in collaboration with arts and cultural organizations, and science and education institutions. With all of our projects, Wisdom seeks to correct misconceptions, end prejudice, bring health and wellness to Native people, and demonstrate how Indian culture has and continues to enrich our worlds.

This Project...

Wisdom of the Elders Radio, Series Four: Indigenous Response to Climate Change, eight one-hour Native American public radio programs for a national audience, is an oral history, cultural arts and climate science series featuring the voices of exemplary Native elders, storytellers, song carriers and scientists who provide Traditional Ecological Knowledge and unique perspective on environment and climate issues. 

Our production team traveled to Alaska in August and September to record Native elders for Wisdom’s fourth radio series, this time on climate and cultural issues. Wisdom Radio has aired on Native American, public and community radio stations nationwide since 2002. Wisdom Radio Series Four: Indigenous Response to Climate Change, is funded by National Endowment for the Arts but we need to raise 1:1 matching funds. So we are asking for your help. 

This is where you come in...

Though woefully under-paid for their skills and talents, our 12-member production team is committed to this work. Your contribution to our Indiegogo will help produce these 8 one-hour radio programs and provide our producers with a decent fee.

The first two programs will be produced by June 2014 with the remaining six one-hour programs to be produced over the next two years.

Other ways to help...

Network among your friends and colleagues and let them know about Wisdom of the Elders, our Radio Series, and other programs. Share our Indiegogo via Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn, Tumblr, Email, everywhere! 

Please subscribe to our newsletter and find out more about Wisdom at www.wisdomoftheelders.org.

Thank you!

story:
HOME BAKED ELECTRICS

I’m building an Electric Motorcycle. Not your everyday senior in high school project, but I wanted to prove that we can all make transportation a bit more efficient and a lot kinder to the environment.

WHY I NEED YOUR HELP: To complete the design and realize a street-worthy vehicle that can operate in L.A. traffic I need the following:

  1. 125 amp 40 Hp Brushless electric motor $820
  2. 6 Winston LFP40AH 3.2V, 40Ah $360
  3. PG drives, Alltrax, or sevcon controller with regen $380-$440
  4. Magura Twist Grip 5k throttle $50
  5. AllBright Contactor $85
  6. Cycle Analyst Speedometer $175
  7. Shumacher Multi-rate Charger $295

costs $2095-$2155

That’s a bit much for me, considering college next year

My boss, Justin Kell (owner of GLORY MOTORWORKS) has been incredibly supportive already: not only have I learned a lot, but he’s donating parts and helping me in the design process. Also thanks to Gary Chapman for design assistance, and my parents for emotional support and putting up with my love of motorcycles.

I’ve gotten the following already and have begun the process of creating the bike: A motorcycle frame - Wheels and Tires – Brakes – Seat - Foot Controls - Gear Box – Headlights – Brake –Lights - Electrical Switches – Speedometer - Mounting Gear

I have all the parts I could ever need

Seriously, I’ve been working with bikes for over two years: I became an intern at GLORY MOTORWORKS when I was 16 and I’ve been there ever since.

I’m also attuned to design, environmental needs, and the power of doing your own. Help support this project. The party to unveil the bike is on Saturday, July 27th, location TBA. I hope you’ll support the project.

This can be yours to hang over your bed and haunt your dreams.

story:
This campaign is about wildlife conservation and historic preservation.

A developer wants to put 276 rental units just upland of Fowl Meadow and sort of in the middle of these three unique habitats of Blue Hills mature upland forests, the marshy flood plains of Fowl Meadow and the open fields and meadows of the historic Blue Hill Farms neighborhoods.

A fraction of the units would be considered affordable so this project can bypass the local planning and zoning board restrictions.

There are streams and brooks and water that come down through the proposed development site, some of this water comes all the way from the Blue Hills.

The uplands act as a filtration system for this water that comes down into Fowl Meadow. Several public and private water supply wells are located within the Fowl Meadow area.  

The wetlands in the site are really important as are the vernal pools down beneath it. These waters are the beginnings of life that is significant for our ecology.  

We recently found a blue spotted salamander between the proposed site and the Fowl Meadow. They stay in the upland area most of the year and then trek down to the same vernal pool where they were born once a year to mate.  Blanding turtles make the opposite trek to lay their eggs in the upland.  These animals and others need these different habitats kept intact in order to survive.

There are traffic and saftey concerns for this area as well as the impact on two historical neighborhoods dating back to the 1700 and 1800's. And this area is rich in Native American history with three archaeological sites within a half mile of this development site.

So while we agree that affordable housing is important, we believe that other things that I have hit on here are also important and need their fair hearing and protections. In order to get these concerns heard we need to document all of this and more.

We need experts in law, water, environment, traffic, emergency access, history, and archaeology to weigh in. We need to get time extensions when possible.

We could use your help and support. Become a Friend of Hemenway Woods and donate to the cause of wildlife conservation and historic preservation.

If you can take advantage of some of these perks we would love to share some of the natural and historic resources of the community with you!!

Sharing this link with your friends and family is also quite helpful!!

This treasured area has been protected by generations before us. 

It is our turn to step up and do what we can!

story:
Did you know that every spring wild birds make a courageous thousands of kilometers journey in order to migrate with almost no stops to sleep, rest, feed or drink?

Did you know that a significant percentage of them never make it to their destination due to exhaustion and starvation?

Did you know that, every spring, the birds that survive to land in the most beautiful stop over sites in Greece, the Ionian islands, get shot and never reach Northern Europe in order to reproduce?

Did you know that hunting during spring has been banned since 1985, but it is still not properly enforced in Greece?

Well… If you help us raise sufficient funds for our “A Safe Ηaven for Wild Birds” campaign you and thousands of others will find out and put this illegal and catastrophic activity where is belongs: in the past!

 

Why Wild Birds need Your Help

Illegal killing during spring migration has taken place for decades in the Ionian Islands (more intensely in Zakynthos, Strofadia, Corfu, Paxoi and Othonoi), as these are situated along a major bird migratory route. This illegal activity is deeply engrained in the local culture. It also represents an economic benefit for the local community, as land in the best “spots” is rented out expensively during about three weeks between end of March and the early April. The illegal activity in the Ionian Islands is particularly severe: HOS surveys indicate that gunshot numbers may reach up to 15,000 per day during a day with “good” south winds.

The main species targeted is the Turtle Dove (Streptopelia turtur), whose conservation status is classified as ‘Unfavourable’ in the EU. According to BirdLife International (2004, Birds in the European Union), its populations have declined by 10% since 1980. Moreover, the negative trend was caused by the ongoing habitat destruction and unsustainable levels of exploitation, part of which is illegal killing. During the illegal spring killing, several other species of migratory raptors and herons are shot as well such as Hen harrier (Circus cyaneus), Marsh harriere (C. aeruginosus), Red-footed Falcon (Falco vespertinus), Kestrel (F. tinnunculus), and herons.

Killing of migratory birds takes place during the return of the birds from Africa to the breeding grounds in Europe. The Ionian Islands are the first stopover for rest on route towards Northern Europe. They provide refuge and food for the arriving birds which are particularly vulnerable. Recent research by the Technological Educational Institute of the Ionian Islands and HOS has shown that the Turtle Doves that land in the Ionian Islands have below average body masses compared to those occurring in other parts of the Mediterranean in the same period, due to the longer distance they have to cover for reaching the east Mediterranean.

The main problem this campaign is tackling is the almost total lack of awareness among the general public, the authorities and the younger generation regarding the EU’s spring hunting ban, which was imposed in the 1980’s. Even though three decades have passed, Greece is not implementing the ban properly.

 

A Safe haven for Wild Birds objectives

The aim of the campaign is to reduce illegal killing of migratory wild birds in Greece during spring and this is happening in coordination with another two Mediterranean countries where illegal killing is still fairly common: Italy and Spain.

Our specific objectives of the campaign are:

  • To change the socio-cultural attitudes towards illegal killing in the younger generation.
  • To raise the awareness of local communities, local authorities, hunters and the wider public along the migratory flyways of the species affected by the illegal activities.
  • To improve law enforcement, through increased awareness and better coordination among law enforcement authorities.

 

Who are we?

Hellenic Ornithological Society (HOS) is an environmental non-governmental organization for the protection of wild birds and their habitats in Greece.

We were founded in 1982 by passionate bird lovers and scientists and our mission is to ensure a sustainable natural environment for birds and people.

As evidence to the continuous efforts and contributions of HOS to the protection of Greece’s natural environment, it was awarded the Environmental Protection Award by the National Academy in 1993.

Since 1994, the Hellenic Ornithological Society has been a partner of Birdlife International, the world’s largest organization concerned with the protection of birds and their habitats.

A significant result of our partnership was the inclusion of the Important Bird Areas in the European ‘ Natura 2000’ Network of protected areas.

HOS’ main focus is on:

  • Research on birds and their habitats, in order to implement actions of protection and conservation
  • Raising of public awareness regarding the natural environment, through operation of information centers throughout Greece, public awareness events, environmental education in schools and campaigning for crucial environmental issues and the effective implementation of environmental law
  • Site intervention advocacy and policy making for crucial environmental issues
  • Protection of birds and management of their habitats (monitoring of protected areas, population census, enhancement of the natural environment, habitats management and restoration)

Our capacity

During the last decade HOS has implemented successfully 8 LIFE Nature projects aimed at the protection of priority bird species and their habitats. We are also responsible for monitoring and updating the Important Bird Areas network in Greece and have achieved the designation of the majority of these IBAs as SPAs of the Natura 2000 Network. Recently, it has scanned Greece’s seas in order to designate the marine IBA network!

There is therefore a strong, committed and experienced team at HOS that has taken on the task of implementing the campaign.

 

What we have done so far against illegal killing

HOS has campaigned against illegal killing of wild birds throughout its work since 1983. More specifically, HOS has applied pressure to the national and local authorities in order to improve the transposition of the EU’s Birds Directive (that is, the oldest European legislation tool for the protection of biodiversity!) and to actually implement it on the ground.

Illegal killing in the Ionian Islands has been a key media action of HOS every year for the last four years, as we are seeing the Turtle Dove population rapidly reducing. However, more recently HOS has undertaken a series of data collection, lobbying, capacity building and media actions in order to create a clearer and realistic picture of what is happening on the ground, as well as find what are the exact reasons for not tackling the problem are.

This work has lead us to decide to launch the “Safe Ηaven for Wild Birds” three-year  campaign in August 2012, in order to address the problem in a more coordinated, effective and targeted manner.

The campaign’s overall budget in Greece is 120.000 €. The EU will partially finance the project with the amount of 60.000 €. The remaining amount (60.000€) is self-financed. This is of course a very difficult task due to the economic crisis in Greece and the dropping out of potential greek funders. So, your contribution is absolutely helpful for the continuation and the completion of this campaign!

 

What we will do with YOUR help!

1)      A “Safe Haven for Wild Birds” national campaign. HOS will deliver a three-year campaign that targets hunters associations, visitors, decision makers and the younger generation. The campaign will go through stages of growing level of involvement of the target audiences using a number of different channels and tools: press adverts, TV spot, radio spot, engagement in social networks, and printed materials such as posters and pins.

ESTIMATED COST: 21.000 €

 

2)      Local campaign in the Ionian islands: a series of local events and information kiosks in Zakynthos and Corfu throughout the summer months of the three years of the campaign aim to engage local communities and our volunteers. We will also organize a “training the media” session in Zante in order to increase sensitivity around spring killing in the local media.

ESTIMATED COST: 29,000 €

 

3)      Production of a short documentary in Greece regarding the spring killing of wild birds in the Ionian islands. The documentary will analyze the roots of this illegal activity and give voice to those negatively affected by it. The video will be presented at numerous environmental film festivals and will be available on the project website.

ESTIMATED COST: 13,000 €

 

4)      Environmental education campaign at local level in Greece. The younger generations will be informed though an environmental education package for 250 schools in the Ionian Islands and the local Environmental Education Centers.

ESTIMATED COST: 17,000 €

 

5)      International workshop on Bird Crime in Greece. The workshop will raise the awareness of the law enforcement agencies and the decision makers about the extent of illegal killing of birds in the Mediterranean and will facilitate the exchange of best practices in persecuting the illegal bird killers across the Mediterranean.

ESTIMATED COST: 12,000 €

 

6)      Mobile exhibition in the Ionian Islands: all results of the campaign and the schoolchildren’s paintings that will be produced during the environmental education campaign will be toured in the Ionian Islands during the summer of 2015.

ESTIMATED COST: 5,000 €

 

The Impact

Your contribution is essential for the continuation of this campaign. Without it HOS might not be able to secure the amount needed for the self-financing of the campaign and therefore not implement the campaign fully.

Bear in mind that this is in line with the most important and ambitious European Commission’s initiatives to stop the loss of biodiversity and to conserve the European ecosystems. It is also an important initiative in order to promote and achieve the European Council’s Larnaka Declaration, to “recognise the significance of the illegal taking and trade of birds as a risk to the achievement and maintenance of favorable status of bird populations […]and resulting in adverse impacts on the conservation, legal hunting, agriculture and tourism sector”.

 

What You Get

The thread between us, the local communities and the younger generation is YOU! Your contribution will guarantee we will reach the hearts and ears of people through this campaign.

In return, we have thought of some rewards to show our gratitude (see the perks listed in the right)!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

YOU can wear the campaign’s pin and become an advocate for the “Safe Haven for Wild Birds” campaign.

YOU can talk about this campaign with your family, friends, colleagues... everyone in your local community and spread the message around to as many people as you can using your social media accounts.

YOU can become a member of HOS and receive our magazine and all events updates.

Help us defend bird migration by visiting:

  • Campaign’s website  www.leavingisliving.org
  • Facebook page (in greek) http://www.facebook.com/safehavenforwildbirds.

You’ll look at the sky with different eyes...

 

With the contribution of the LIFE financial instrument of the European Union

Did you know that every spring wild birds make a courageous thousands of kilometers journey in order to migrate with almost no stops to sleep, rest, feed or drink?
Did you know that a significant percentage of them never make it to their destination due to exhaustion and starvation?
Did you know that, every spring, the birds that survive to land in the most beautiful stop over sites in Greece, the Ionian islands, get shot and never reach Northern Europe in order to reproduce?
Did you know that hunting during spring has been banned since 1985, but it is still not properly enforced in Greece?
Well… If you help us raise sufficient funds for our “A Safe Ηaven for Wild Birds” campaign you and thousands of others will find out and put this illegal and catastrophic activity where is belongs: in the past!
 
Why Wild Birds need Your Help
Illegal killing during spring migration has taken place for decades in the Ionian Islands (more intensely in Zakynthos, Strofadia, Corfu, Paxoi and Othonoi), as these are situated along a major bird migratory route. This illegal activity is deeply engrained in the local culture. It also represents an economic benefit for the local community, as land in the best “spots” is rented out expensively during about three weeks between end of March and the early April. The illegal activity in the Ionian Islands is particularly severe: HOS surveys indicate that gunshot numbers may reach up to 15,000 per day during a day with “good” south winds.
The main species targeted is the Turtle Dove (Streptopelia turtur), whose conservation status is classified as ‘Unfavourable’ in the EU. According to BirdLife International (2004, Birds in the European Union), its populations have declined by 10% since 1980. Moreover, the negative trend was caused by the ongoing habitat destruction and unsustainable levels of exploitation, part of which is illegal killing. During the illegal spring killing, several other species of migratory raptors and herons are shot as well such as Hen harrier (Circus cyaneus), Marsh harriere (C. aeruginosus), Red-footed Falcon (Falco vespertinus), Kestrel (F. tinnunculus), and herons.
Killing of migratory birds takes place during the return of the birds from Africa to the breeding grounds in Europe. The Ionian Islands are the first stopover for rest on route towards Northern Europe. They provide refuge and food for the arriving birds which are particularly vulnerable. Recent research by the Technological Educational Institute of the Ionian Islands and HOS has shown that the Turtle Doves that land in the Ionian Islands have below average body masses compared to those occurring in other parts of the Mediterranean in the same period, due to the longer distance they have to cover for reaching the east Mediterranean.

To change the socio-cultural attitudes towards illegal killing in the younger generation.
To raise the awareness of local communities, local authorities, hunters and the wider public along the migratory flyways of the species affected by the illegal activities.
To improve law enforcement, through increased awareness and better coordination among law enforcement authorities.

A significant result of our partnership was the inclusion of the Important Bird Areas in the European ‘ Natura 2000’ Network of protected areas.

Research on birds and their habitats, in order to implement actions of protection and conservation

Site intervention advocacy and policy making for crucial environmental issues
Protection of birds and management of their habitats (monitoring of protected areas, population census, enhancement of the natural environment, habitats management and restoration)

During the last decade HOS has implemented successfully 8 LIFE Nature projects aimed at the protection of priority bird species and their habitats. We are also responsible for monitoring and updating the Important Bird Areas network in Greece and have achieved the designation of the majority of these IBAs as SPAs of the Natura 2000 Network. Recently, it has scanned Greece’s seas in order to designate the marine IBA network!
There is therefore a strong, committed and experienced team at HOS that has taken on the task of implementing the campaign.
