story:
*Special Note - A huge thank you to photographer Mary Holland

Bill's own 'resident black bear' could often be found wandering his property with her new cubs in tow and proved a worthy adversary for Bill in the race for the fresh crop of blueberries each year!

The beautiful black bear featured here and used in this campaign was caught on camera by photographer Mary Holland.  Check out the gallery tab for the full picture of this magnificent animal - absolutely amazing!  Mary was gracious enough to grant me special permission to use this incredible picture in my Indiegogo campaign. You can find out more about Mary ... as well as peruse and enjoy her stunning array of photos here -  www.naturallycuriouswithmaryholland.wordpress.com

Why this campaign and why now?

Why now? 

Bill just died on January 16th of this year.  I'm trying to save the land he protected and loved so much from being sold.

Why the campaign?

I truly believe, with all my heart, that we are all connected in same grand way and therefore what affects me, ultimately affects you too and vice versa. 

I'm trying to prevent the sale and eventual destruction of this magnificent northern forest; I'm hoping to help Bill's family pay off the remaining mortgage and save this amazing expanse of northern Ontario forested land for future generations to come.

CHECK OUT THE "GOOGLE EARTH" IMAGES OF THE PROPERTY, the assortment of pictures, along with a wonderful video of the Dean Lake Bridge area, done by videographer Dean Martin (also know as Simplyred4x4) - you'll find all of these under the "gallery' tab.

Why this is important to us -

First - Bill was passionate about preserving and protecting our national forests.  He believed that these natural, extraordinary and diverse ecosystems, besides being home to a myriad of wildlife species, trees, shrubs, flowers, plants and other unique vegetation, were also the 'lungs of the earth'. 

Although his acreage was limited in size, his heart was huge.  He truly felt that he was contributing toward the fight for the global preservation of these magnificent bio-diverse centers (forests), which without a doubt, are a huge asset to our global environment.  We believe he was right .... if everyone did their part, think of the difference we could make.

Second - This scenic northern area is also where our family began.

William A. Somers Sr. (our father) was born in Copper Cliff, Ontario in 1929.  His father, Mansell Ellwood Somers (our grandfather - wife, Evelyn Somers - nee Paul) eventually became the Reeve of McKim Twp., Sudbury in the 1950s. 

Dad, along with several of his brothers, joined the Canadian Armed Forces when they were just out of their teens - dad was 23. 

After receiving an honorable discharge and retiring from the Army (1973), which also meant his travelling days were over ... and after the sudden death of our mother (1999), dad moved back up North in 2008 and moved in with Bill, where he died in December 2009.

Bill Somers (Jr.) died there January 16th, 2013.

Please help us keep this legacy alive!

Bill’s Story

I’ve started this campaign in honor of my late brother, Bill Somers and on behalf of his two children, Jason Haverson and Mandy Somers (the recipients of this campaign).  Bill died just over a month ago now … he had just turned 59. 

Who Was Bill and What Was He Like?

First and foremost, Bill was always helping someone else ... a friend, a loved one, a neighbour, a stranger.  And besides everything else, Bill was an artist – he played guitar and sang from the time he was in his early teens.  One of his all-time, favorite songs was, “He Ain’t Heavy, He’s My Brother”.  The song says it all, but his life tells the incredible story of hardship, perseverance and triumph.  

Bill’s Legacy – “He’s Ain’t Heavy, He’s My Brother”

On January 16th, 2013 and approximately one month after his birthday, my brother was found dead in his home in Blind River (Dean Lake), the victim of a sudden and massive heart attack.  Bill lived alone on 172 acres of forested property in the Dean Lake area - a wildlife oasis - that above all odds he had managed to purchase, protect and hang onto for almost 18 years, despite his disabilities and the many hardships along the way.  This land was his life … and his love - breathtakingly beautiful, albeit rugged and untamed, just the way it should be.

We found a paper beside Bill when he died – this was the passage it contained:

“Life can be as bitter as dragon tears.  But whether dragon tears are bitter or sweet, depends entirely on how each man perceives the taste.”

In order to tell you how this campaign came about, I need to tell you the story behind it, so please bear with me.  It’s a long story, but I promise you that it’s worth the read.

I lost my older brother Bill to a massive heart attack … Jason and Mandy lost their father … and as it stands right now, they’re also in jeopardy of losing everything he built and fought so hard to keep.  If these two young people don’t get the help they so desperately need … and soon, Bill’s ‘legacy of love’ ends with him. 

18 years ago, after a heart-breaking divorce … and after living in southern Ontario for almost twenty years, Bill decided to move north and begin his life again.  Bill’s troubles had been many but over the years since his move North, he had faced them head-on … he overcame each one, conquered his fears and demons (which included alcohol addiction) and then finally, lived a life of gratitude and thankfulness.  He developed an appreciation for all of life and a wisdom that was far beyond his years.  He had a kind heart and an old soul.

Because of a horrific family situation and a life of abuse, Bill had been on his own since he was 16 years old.  After running away from home, he had initially lived on the street, but then shortly thereafter, had been welcomed into his best friend’s family home.  He also lost that dear friend, Glen, in a drowning accident when he was 18.  Bill was always a survivor, but the cruel twists that life dealt him, had also taken their toll. 

In the mid 1990s, he bought 172 acres of northern forest land near Dean Lake, where he lived in a small, but cozy cottage-style home (built on top of a massive rock formation), until his sudden death last month.  He was taken much too early.

Bill loved his property.  He had a true respect for the land and all that it gave him.  He lived a minimalist existence.  He loved the deer, the wolves, the moose, the sand pipers and even the bear he encountered each spring when they surfaced with their new off-spring.  He planted (and shared) a huge vegetable garden and harvested the beautiful northern blueberries found throughout his property – in fact he made the best blueberry scones around, but was constantly trying to beat the resident bear to the various patches!  He learned to live in harmony with nature and the wildlife around him … each taking what they needed from the land and each giving back what was essential to sustain their surroundings … while also showing a healthy respect for each other’s needs and space.

However, the most amazing part of this story is the fact that Bill held onto this land through thick and thin … and he did it, while living on a disability of approx. $1,100.00 per month, faithfully paying his mortgage each and every month.  Besides having painful and debilitating rheumatoid arthritis, along with a heart condition and a blood clotting disorder (that required $120 compression stocking), Bill was also buried in a landslide at the Sand Hills Provincial Park years ago, while vacationing with his young family – an accident that put him in the ICU for weeks and left his lungs forever severely compromised because of the sand.

But this same man made almost daily treks to the bush with his Great Pyrenees 'Brat', who was his constant companion and was always at his side.  Although Bill would never consider logging his property or even cutting down a single living tree, he was forever removing and clearing tangled brush and dead trees, in order to keep the landscape healthy and prevent smaller wildlife from being injured and/or trapped.  He also used the weak, fallen and dead trees as firewood to heat his home.  If his old tractor or truck didn’t run, which was often the case, he would pull the logs home by hand using a ‘huge’ snow scoop … and use the hills and the packed trails as momentum. 

Bill was usually on foot and in the winter months, he used snow shoes and skis to traverse the trails and landscapes.  Huge storms could mean that he was basically ‘snowed-in’ for weeks at a time, so he was always prepared.  There was nothing he loved more than a day out in the bush.   He meticulously mapped his property by marking the trees and various trails with inconspicuous, different colored rope and/or tape. 

Bill had always dreamed about owning land up north and once he followed his vision, everything else in his life seemed to gradually fall into its proper place.  He was happy; he was at peace.  He loved and respected his natural surroundings … it was all he ever talked about.  He made sure that he managed his property in such a way, that it would remain in pristine shape; true to its origin and its natural state.  It would be his legacy to his two children once he was gone.  

I can’t even begin to tell you how proud I was of him and all that he accomplished during his short lifetime.  He was an honest and loyal man; a man of integrity and sacrifice.  If nothing else, this is a story of determination and survival; the story of a man, who despite all odds, managed to overcome and survive his own fears, disabilities, short-comings and demons.  His resilience and perseverance was inspiring, if not downright courageous.  The spirit is a wonderful thing … and Bill’s was indomitable!

Bill was a proud man; a man who worked tirelessly to keep his land from being mercilessly logged or abused.  After he died, we heard so many beautiful stories of his selflessness from neighbors and friends.  Although he spent much of his time alone and for the most part remained isolated, he would always show up whenever there was someone in need. 

One such story immediately comes to mind – the story of a man who had been injured in the mines and was unable to cut and pile his firewood for winter, because of excruciating back pain.  Bill had heard about them on his weekly trip to town and although he had never met the couple, he showed up in their driveway that very same day with his chain-saw and axe in tow.  His first comment after introducing himself, was … “let’s get this done” … and within a couple of days, he had not only cut and piled every stick of dead wood they owned, but went on to reinforce and repair their deck, railings and balcony.  The only thing he would take in return was a free home-cooked meal … and from that day on, they became the best of friends.  Bill was always best at ‘bartering’ for his needs. 

This couple remained close friends with Bill until the day he died … and after staying with them while dealing with his untimely passing, we understood exactly what community spirit was all about.  During our three days in Dean Lake, they recounted many similar instances of kindness, where Bill had helped members of their small community without ever asking for anything in return.  In fact, he would think nothing of spending his last dollar to help someone else … and often did. 

If there weren’t enough provisions in the house, he would still make sure that his faithful dog Brat had food, even if it meant that he went without.  He could survive for months with veggies from his garden (in his freezer), rice, flour, blueberries etc.  He made his own bread and did all his own cooking, despite the fact that regular money for groceries was usually non-existent.  He did this for eighteen years!

This was the area he loved; an area he was so proud to call home.  Bill paid his mortgage faithfully but according to his bank, was not eligible for life insurance (he applied and was turned down).  When he died, there was still approximately $40,000.00 owing on the mortgage, not to mention the funeral and burial expenses.  It’s devastating! 

I’d like to create the opportunity for his children to hang on to his house and his property. Unfortunately, as it stands now, neither of them has the resources to take on this huge debt … and I myself, am in no position to help with finances.

Toward the end of his life, he worried constantly about finances and how he would survive … but his biggest worry was how to keep his property and his legacy alive … it was something that he felt so passionate about – a ‘legacy of love’ that could be passed on to his two children and then perhaps someday, on to his grandchildren.  His final wishes were to have his ashes spread throughout his beautiful property at DeanLake. 

Every now and again a story comes along that defies all logic and tears away at your heartstrings, until you can’t help but wonder where the justice is in any of this.

Stories of loss, of abuse, of heartache and injustice are everywhere, but incidents of triumph should surely share the spotlight.  My brother … my friend … deserves that much.

His family deserves that much.

I’m hoping that this story is one of those – a story of hope and then finally … a story of triumph.

I can’t even begin to tell you how proud I was of him and all that he accomplished during his short lifetime.  He was an honest and loyal man; a man of integrity and sacrifice.  If nothing else, this is a story of determination and survival; the story of a man, who despite all odds, managed to overcome and survive his own fears, disabilities, short-comings and demons.  His resilience and perseverance was inspiring, if not downright courageous.  The spirit is a wonderful thing … and Bill’s was indomitable!
Bill was a proud man; a man who worked tirelessly to keep his land from being mercilessly logged or abused.  After he died, we heard so many beautiful stories of his selflessness from neighbors and friends.  Although he spent much of his time alone and for the most part remained isolated, he would always show up whenever there was someone in need. 
One such story immediately comes to mind – the story of a man who had been injured in the mines and was unable to cut and pile his firewood for winter, because of excruciating back pain.  Bill had heard about them on his weekly trip to town and although he had never met the couple, he showed up in their driveway that very same day with his chain-saw and axe in tow.  His first comment after introducing himself, was … “let’s get this done” … and within a couple of days, he had not only cut and piled every stick of dead wood they owned, but went on to reinforce and repair their deck, railings and balcony.  The only thing he would take in return was a free home-cooked meal … and from that day on, they became the best of friends.  Bill was always best at ‘bartering’ for his needs. 
This couple remained close friends with Bill until the day he died … and after staying with them while dealing with his untimely passing, we understood exactly what community spirit was all about.  During our three days in Dean Lake, they recounted many similar instances of kindness, where Bill had helped members of their small community without ever asking for anything in return.  In fact, he would think nothing of spending his last dollar to help someone else … and often did. 
If there weren’t enough provisions in the house, he would still make sure that his faithful dog Brat had food, even if it meant that he went without.  He could survive for months with veggies from his garden (in his freezer), rice, flour, blueberries etc.  He made his own bread and did all his own cooking, despite the fact that regular money for groceries was usually non-existent.  He did this for eighteen years!
This was the area he loved; an area he was so proud to call home.  Bill paid his mortgage faithfully but according to his bank, was not eligible for life insurance (he applied and was turned down).  When he died, there was still approximately $40,000.00 owing on the mortgage, not to mention the funeral and burial expenses.  It’s devastating! 
I’d like to create the opportunity for his children to hang on to his house and his property. Unfortunately, as it stands now, neither of them has the resources to take on this huge debt … and I myself, am in no position to help with finances.
Toward the end of his life, he worried constantly about finances and how he would survive … but his biggest worry was how to keep his property and his legacy alive … it was something that he felt so passionate about – a ‘legacy of love’ that could be passed on to his two children and then perhaps someday, on to his grandchildren.  His final wishes were to have his ashes spread throughout his beautiful property at DeanLake. 
Every now and again a story comes along that defies all logic and tears away at your heartstrings, until you can’t help but wonder where the justice is in any of this.
Stories of loss, of abuse, of heartache and injustice are everywhere, but incidents of triumph should surely share the spotlight.  My brother … my friend … deserves that much.
His family deserves that much.
I’m hoping that this story is one of those – a story of hope and then finally … a story of triumph.

story:
We are a group of families, building together an Eco-Community center in central Israel. We have taken an old chicken-coop from the 1950's, and are renovating it using straw-bales, earth, stone, recycled materials such as bottles, glass jars, and more... 

In the process of building the center, we have already saved SEVERAL TONS of garbage that would otherwise be lying in garbage dumps!! 

You can view pictures of the renovation process here: 

http://www.bayadaim.org.il/2012/07/%D7%A9%D7%99%D7%A4%D7%95%D7%A5-%D7%90%D7%A7%D7%95%D7%9C%D7%95%D7%92%D7%99/ 

(the text is in Hebrew but the photos speak for themselves...)

All the work on the center is 100% voluntary! We build it together: women, men, youth, children, elderly people - everyone is always made welcome in this space.  

The center's aims are: 

  • To promote sustainable education and Permaculture in our region - (workshops in mud-building, bio-intensive agriculture, community building; Eco-activities for children, youth and adults, and more...)
  • To serve as an open home for the local community - free exchange markets take place here once a month, "green" events, community gardening, local "time bank", etc 
  • To promote alternative education for children: the centre will be used by our local homeschooling community, as a place where our children can grow up together with us as a community. Instead of going to a regular school, they will learn from life itself the skills they will need for a better future for humankind. 

 

What We Need - 

Up until now, we managed to build the walls of the ecocenter with virtually no funding at all and LOTS of volunteer work. The funds came from fundraising markets and workshops that we initiated. 

Now, we have come across bigger expenses, broken down as follows: 

  • $7894 - replacing the old roof with a new one 
  • $2606 - replacing the old windows and fitting in a very large door at one of the openings.  
  • There are many other expenses of course, but if we get these two bigger expenses funded, we will be able to use the Center itself as a place by which to raise further funds. 

If we don't reach the full goal, we will first fund the windows, and then hope to raise more funds for replacing the roof.  

What You Get - 

Some of the things we offer in return to your support are available if you live in Israel: discounts for workshops, community events, and other services we offer. 

However, if you live outside of Israel, you can still enjoy being mentioned on our website, or even having your name engraved on one of the Center's earth walls or earth floor!

For larger-sum donators, we can send an electronic version of our booklet "Sustainable Community Building - from single family units to cooperation" - a manual that includes articles about community building, sustainable education, how to initiate and maintain an exchange market, and more. 

We wish to inspire other communities around the world! Larger-sum donators will also get a free Skype call with one of our community leaders who will be happy to answer any of your questions and help your community dream become a reality! 

Planning a trip to Israel? We can organize a free tour of the Center for you and your friends plus a half-day workshop on a topic of your choice: mud-building, permaculture, community building and more... We will be happy to host you here! 

 

Why is this so important? 

We are living in an exciting and challenging era. 

The world is changing: economic, social and environmental crises are taking place and the challenges are likely to increase as time goes by. 

Centers like ours are the future! We are building a social, economic and environmental alternative through which we can pass on the knowledge and ancient wisdom of connection between ourselves and the natural world. In this manner, we will be able to cope together with the challenges, and perhaps even form a network of communities helping each other out.

Our Center promotes not only a "greener" tomorrow, but also aims to promote better communication between people by fostering the values of cooperation, honesty, modesty, listening, empathy and caring. 

We welcome you to help us continue our work towards our vision! We and our children will be forever grateful. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't help us out financially, we would very much appreciate it if you could spread the word through the various sharing tools - Facebook, Tweeter, and all the rest!

story:
I have been practicing doing monthly horoscopes for 7 and a half years
through my youtube comedy channel called SEXY ASTROLOGY.  No, I do
not think I am sexy, but in the world of astrology the two words are easy
to remember. And being that the show is grounded in comedy, my husband
and I came up with the idea after I had my 3rd child and the result was
a small smash!  I have over 2 million video views and being that astrology is a
topic which many take way too seriously-or people just don't believe in it at all-I thought how can I sell my advice better?  Make it SEXY, but the bottom line is keeping it simple only offer one or two simple ideas & keep it funny so people 
keep coming back!  It's a self-help show, with a bent on comedy and art...
Astrology is one of those topics, that needs to be televised...

The reason I am interested in keeping my Trade Mark is that in the last year
someone else started using the term "Sexy Astrology" with their column.
I thought, "oh no..." guess I'll apply for a trade mark.   The United State Patent and
Trademark Office approved it as of June 6, 2014.  I am so excited!
However I did not expect someone to file a notice of Opposition, and Cease and Desist letter which I recently received.  So I am raising money to hire my lawyer to Defend the trademark.  I have a strong case and over the years, 400 pages of
notes, from my monthly readings and a VERY different product from the person
who is trying to take it down.  Intellectual property is important to all of us!
If I am able to secure my trademark I will be able to continue to use the name
Sexy Astrology for my show.  And who knows? possibly obtain a slot on CNN,
for a season or two, Ok Cable Access, maybe the History Channel? O?  Bio?
What I need is exactly 1200.00$ for the Answer to the Notice of Opposition.
Plus an additional 1000.00$ for the follow up.   I know I can come up with the
rest of what ever goal I don't reach.  All of the Funds are going to my Trade
Mark attorney in Los Angeles.

Don't worry of course If you can't contribute keep coming back and I will see
you on the Movie Screen.

story:
The Uluwatu Project

We are passionate about saving Uluwatu and this site is used to receive online donations from around the world, as international bank transfers have high banking fees - fees that could be put to good use here in Indonesia. All donations through this site will go directly to the Eco Surf Rescue Uluwatu (ESRU) bank account within the registered non-profit organization GUS Foundation and will be used for the betterment of Uluwatu. The goal is to raise $50,000 USD in total.

Expect a more complete page in the future, or visit our main project page here.

For now, please learn a little more about the project and make a secure donation via credit card.

Who is Involved:

The brainchild of two residents, Jon and Ollie, ESRU was formed when local NGOs,  GUS Foundation and R.O.L.E. Foundation, teamed up with the surf industry, local businesses and residents.

Active members of the committee include:

Paola Cannucciari (ecoBali Recycling)

James Hendy (Rip Curl Asia)

Ollie Crowell and Tim Russo (Uluwatu Surf Villas)

Curtis Lowe 

Jon Huberman

Steve Palmer

Julianus (JDR B.S. Construction Company)

Mike O’Leary (R.O.L.E. Foundation)

Ani Yulinda (GUS Foundation)

Antonio Portinari (Art In Surf)

Our Vision:

A future of clean and pristine waves stewarded by an environmentally conscious community that recognizes the special beauty and significance of Uluwatu.

Our Mission:

Plan, design, build and manage a solid and liquid waste infrastructure system to preserve and restore the ravine and cave ecosystems.

  • Become a sustainable, non-profit project assisted by the surf industry for the benefit of local residents, surfers and coastal visitors.
  • To be managed and operated by the local community for the benefit of the community and visitors to Uluwatu.
  • Create a successful case study that can be replicated in other ‘environmentally-troubled’ surf areas in Indonesia, and globally.

Accomplishments to date:

  • 30 tons of solid waste and rubbish were removed from the ravine in June of 2011.
  • Daily collection of rubbish from the Uluwatu cliffside shops and warungs, where local ladies were employed by GUS Foundation began shortly after.
  • 3 times weekly the rubbish that has been carried up the steps is collected by ecoBali RECYCLING.
  • A large permanent concrete waste bin constructed by the R.O.L.E. Foundation.
  • Distribution of over 40 organic and non-organic rubbish bins accompanied by educational talks by ecoBali.
  • Professional surveying and topographical mapping of the Cliffside and shop areas completed before final design of the Liquid Waste and Sewerage System were drawn up by JDR B.S. Consultants.
  • Formation of a local council on waste and growth in April 2012 merged with ESRU.
  • Used cooking oil collection program beginning now: Swiss NGO Caritas has donated a storage tank to include Uluwatu in their bio-fuel production project.  Used oil will be purchased by the liter and will help make the project slightly more self-sustainable. Plus, it will keep the used oil from polluting our environment.

Next Steps:

Raise $50,000 USD to install and manage the proposed liquid waste system.

Build a composting area so all organic waste can go towards gardens in the future – and save energy, as it’s the one kind of waste that doesn’t need to be carried up the steps.

Complete the World Surfing Heritage site application.

Hand over management to the local committee.

Ensure the future of Uluwatu is bright and green!

http://ecosurfrescue.moonfruit.com/

 Awesome Place, Awesome People, Doing Awesome Things

If you would like to volunteer your time or skills, we'd love to hear from you:

ESRUluwatu@gmail.com

story:
I am incredibly lucky to be amongst 60 people to have been selected from 6,000 global applicants to join Polar Explorer Robert Swan on his personal mission to make Antarctica the one place on earth that the human population will leave alone. 

His project called 2041 campaigns and educates  around the moratorium on Antarctic mining, oil drilling and activity which ends in 2041.  Through Swan's " Leadership On The Edge Program '' he hopes to inspire, educate and inform future leaders and sustainability champions whom he wants to take responsibility and inspire their own communities to change.

The trip lasts three weeks where Antarctic Ambassadors are educated on a base in Antarctica, about stewardship, conservation and the future of renewable energies. They then return home to inspire others and replace themselves with other ambassadors for future 2041 expeditions.

As a contribution to the cost of the trip, the charity asks for a £12,000 donation, which subsidises trip costs for others, provides money for global campaigns  and goes towards education programs. In May 2015 I will be returning to Uganda to teach and find a replacement ambassador for the 2016 trip.

I have attached a link to a online PDF document with more details about 2041, its mission and its leader Rob Swan: http://www.pdf.investintech.com/preview/9b7a4b8...


"Our mission for The International Antarctic Expedition is to create ambassadors for education, the environment and sustainability across the globe. To protect Antarctica and the rest of our planet, we must inspire leaders to return home and create change on the personal level, community level, corporate level and beyond"


Please join me in this critical effort to save the earth's last natural wilderness and follow me in my journey to teach and inspire others about the most fragile continent on earth and the challenge it faces for survival.

Please get in touch with any suggestions for the page, pitch or with any help you maybe to give the 2041 project

How to follow us

The Twitter Page link: https://twitter.com/2041Antarctica

Live blog updates from Antarctica on Facebook:2041robertswan

Twitter: @2041robertswan

story:
10 BACKCOUNTRY LEAN-TO SHELTERS

Plus 10 Composting Latrines

On 165 Miles of Wilderness Hiking

We're an all-volunteer nonprofit organization--The Cohos Trail Association-- building shelters on the long-distance Cohos Trail that we planned and built over the last decade, the longest new hiking trail system created in the eastern United States in decades. We've constructed three lean-to shelters so far, plus their accompanying aerobic composting latrines and sign kiosks. But we want to triple our efforts.

WHAT WE'LL DO AND WHERE

There are seven more shelters and their composting latrines planned in rugged mountainous terrain stretching from the White Mountain National Forest of New Hampshire (the Northeast's tallest peaks) all the way to the Canadian border, where the trail links with the 70-mile Sentiers Frontaliers hiking trail system in Quebec, Canada, to create the second international trail system on the continent.

HOW WE'LL DO IT

Your gift will support the purchase of water-power sawmill-sawn locally grown lumber, metal roofing, cement, fasteners, and stains. Your dollars will provide funds for transporting materials and will underwrite food and supplies for all the volunteers who come out to build the shelter on-site in backcountry locations. And your funds will help bring much needed economic activity to one of the more economically depressed regions of the Northeast.

WHO WILL BENEFIT?

The shelters will be spaced out along the vast Cohos Trail system about ten to twelve miles apart, allowing hikers, wildlife watchers, peakbaggers, school and scout groups and many more outdoors enthusiasts to spend up to ten nights in the Great North Woods without having to carry a tent. All shelters are free to the public at all times and they always will be.

WHY WE'LL DO IT

The trail and its shelters are our attempt to introduce the public to vast tracts of beautiful wilderness land that must forever be protected from development. By building shelters so people may experience these forests and mountains intimately, we hope to be able to motivate more and more people to take action to help preserve these great spaces.

WHO WE ARE: The Cohos Trail Association

Featured in the following publications: National Geographic Adventure, Backpacker magazine, Outside magazine, Air Trans flight magazine, Outdoors (magazine of the Appalachian Mountain Club), the Boston Sunday Globe.

Featured on the following television shows: Windows on the Wild, Crossroads, NHPTV

http://cohostrail.org

http://www.facebook.com/#!/groups/153039451407973/

http://cohostrail.org
http://www.facebook.com/#!/groups/153039451407973/

story:
What is an Olo Bead?

Dimensions: 1.5" x 1" x 1" of food grade HDPE.




The oloid shape was discovered in the 1920's as the best mixer/agitator.  It allowed aggregates to be mixed in a matter of hours instead of days.

Today, the oloid shape can be found on ponds and waste water treatment facilities.


What we have done is shrunk the shape to 1.5" x 1" x 1" and engineered it out of HDPE (High Density Polyethylene) or from the same material a plastic milk jug is made.  Because the density of HDPE (.95 g/cc) is slightly less dense than that of water (1 g/cc) we added a little hydrated magnesium silicate (Talcum Powder with a specific gravity of 2.6 g/cc) to the mix to give the Olo Beads more weight so they spin, rotate, and travel through your laundry more efficiently and effectively without completely sinking or floating on top.  The Olo Beads are non-toxic, will not clog or damage your washing machine, and if you accidentally put a few in your dryer they will not melt, warp, or off-gas harmful chemicals.  The HDPE we use is FDA approved food grade quality.


How Do I Use Olo Beads?

Thanks to its unique, patent pending design, a single bag of Olo Beads poured into your washing machine gets your laundry cleaner with HALF the detergent and in HALF the time.  Olo Beads will not dissolve or disintegrate.  Pour the bag into your laundry machine and just leave them in there!  Olo Beads come with a lifetime warranty so they will last you for life! No need to spend a penny to replace them and you’ll never worry about them doing their job.


How Do Olo Beads Work in My Washing Machine to Get My Clothes Cleaner?

Our Olo Beads work along the same lines as washing boards used over a century ago. A bag of Olo Beads act like tiny wash boards scrubbing your clothes clean in any wash cycle.  Because Olo Beads are constantly cleaning your clothes you can cut your detergent use in half saving you money on every load of laundry you wash each and every time – month in and month out.  Since our Olo Beads don’t wear down, get used up, or otherwise deteriorate, your single purchase of a bag of Olo Beads will save you hundreds upon hundreds of dollars in laundry detergent.


Are Olo Beads Safe? Will They Damage My Clothes or My Washing Machine?

Not at all.  Olo Beads are made out of the same type of plastic used for milk jugs.  The material is harmless and cannot possibly ruin your clothes or break your washing machine.  Much safer than metal buttons or zippers!



What Will Be My Cost Savings?

When I described Olo Beads to a friend of mine from high school with a wife and 3 children, Wagner P., he told me he spends $30 or so a month on laundry.  Cutting that amount in half would mean a $15 savings per month.  "After 2 months the Olo Beads will have paid for themselves!"

Here's the other cost saving feature, but you will have to be more involved with your washing machine, so you can cut down on the time your machine spends in the 'wash' cycle.

  • Time the minutes your washing machine spends in the wash cycle.
  • Subtract that in half.
  • Then when you use Olo Beads for the first time and start your washer, set your watch or your phone to alert you.
  • When your timer goes off, fast forward your washing machine to the first rinse cycle and let your laundry finish out.
  • Another trick: if your laundry uses half the detergent then you might not need 2 rinse cycles - just one.  It all depends on your detergent, the amount you use, and your washing machine.


Olo Beads have already been engineered and prototyped.  We just need the funds to mass produce them for everybody!


Where Will The Money Go?

We are looking to raise $18,500 during this campaign.  Here is where the funds will go:



The Impact on You and the Planet

There are 2 things that will be impacted with your use of Olo Beads:
 
  1. They will save you money by cutting your use of laundry detergent in half while halving your electrical costs - half the time & half the expense!  You will recover the cost of your Olo Beads in less than 2 months!
  2. They will help keep our environment cleaner because we won't be using all of that detergent.


When Can I Expect to Receive My Olo Beads?

Once the campaign is successful by Monday, July 18th and we receive the funds we will order the mold to be made.  Then, sample parts will need to be shipped to us for testing and approval.  After that we will have the Olo Beads mass produced and shipped to you sometime in August.



About The Inventor


Jamie Buturff entered the construction industry after school where he managed multimillion dollar projects for MM Systems as well has having invented several UL Approved life safety devices for the Toronto International Airport. He later became the operations manager for Mercedes International which included product development as well as operations. After having consulted at the Pentagon concerning sensitive computer rooms and the design of special eavesdropping prevention systems he moved to Florida and started a residential construction logistics and installation company. But, after his spiritual awakening just a few years prior, he could not continue down this familiar path in the construction industry.

Jamie moved to Arizona in 2006 and started Spiritual Results Consulting and landed the Chicago White Sox as one of his first clients. Then in January 2009 began research into alternative energy leading him to discover Marko Rodin’s work in Vortex-Based Mathematics.  He  presented several devices of his own design at the Extraordinary Technology Conference in Albuquerque, NM in July of 2009 and ended up on the front page of the Sedona Red Rock News headlining this energy technology breakthrough. He is the author of "The Pre-Secret", which is a workbook available on Amazon.com and teaches how to achieve the all important energetic balance in the body, mind, and soul for health, empowerment and creative flow so the teaching of The Secret will actually work for people.

Jamie is currently the owner of 432 Design, LLC in Sedona, AZ where he resides and invents.


The Future...

story:
About me and my dream, and where the money will go

While and after my journey I will write Books about my adventures, experiences and everything what I did on my way. And only You can get this Books for less money!

I want to motivate other people to hike and to think about the environment during our travels! That's one of many reasons why I want to write the books!

My childhood wasn't the nicest, my parents separated when I was 7, but they didn't stop to fight.
When I was young I realized, that hiking help me a lot to deal with it and forget it for a time. I hiked with friends when I was 12 to 19 years old.After my school I started to work for the St John's Ambulance, later for the Red Cross. That jobs wasn't nice as I had to take many injured people to a lot of hospitals, to evacuate many thounsand humans because someone has found one of many dud bombs from the First and the Second World War. I realized that this is not what I want to do for the rest of my life.

I want to start to realize my dream: to hike through the Canada, Alaska and then around the world. Start should be in the in Canada, then cross Alaska to the Bering street. Subsequently cross Asia, Europe and South America, the US and back to Canada. I don't know how many years I need for this journey. But it doesn't matter.

The only problem is: how can I realize my dream with less money?

You can help me to finance the start of my childhood-dream. Donate just $1. If 400 people each donates US $1, we have $400.

While I am on my journey I will find work on the way. Or maybe I can earn a bit money with my  blog. I just need a money for the first few month.

​I want to motivate other people to hike and to think about the environment during our travels! That's one of many reasons why I want to write the books!

Where the money will go?

  • publishing my books to everybody
  • warm clothes
  • snowshoes
  • my Food for the first weeks
  • maybe a sled
  • Bear spray

And yes, of course I work, but I don't get enough to do this trip.

Follow me on my Blog: https://laurasweltreisewunder.com, on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/Laura-Sophie-Schulz-21..., on Twitter: https://twitter.com/LauraSophieSch3?lang=de and during my journey on YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC6Och_8a6zpYx9... or write "Meine Reise Teil 1" in the search line and subscribe my account.

What will happen, if we don't reach the entire goal?

If we all together don't reach the entire goal the money will also go in this project.

 

Others

If You want to know more about my trip just contact me on l.aura-sophie1schulz@web.de.

Ah, and before I forget: feel free to use the Indiegogo share tools.

story:
Green Elephant Recycling

Green Elephant Recycling allows you the convenience of curbside recycling pick up and the opportunity to recycle more than what our city recycling center currently accepts. Here is what we will be accepting:

  • Shredded paper, newspaper, and junk mail
  • Cardboard (broken down)
  • #1-#7 plastic containers (rinsed with no lids or caps)
  • Green, brown, and clear glass containers (rinsed with no lids or caps)
  • Steel and aluminum cans (rinsed with no lids or caps)

What We Need 

To be able to offer the convenience of curbside pick up and allow a wider range of materials to be recycled, we will need to make sure there is enough interest to cover expenses (cost of fuel) and make this business profitable. So here is what we need:

  • 20 people to pledge 3 months worth of pick up ($90)
  • You to share this with all your friends and family to meet this goal!

The Impact

Most of us understand that recycling is being a good steward of the land we have been given, but this also helps our city. This will reduce the amount of trash that our city has to pick up and pay to dump. So not only are you helping the planet, but you are also helping by making an economic investment into our city.

Risks & Challenges

We want to be open and honest about this new adventure. It will not be easy. Here are some things that we will not know until we jump right in and do it:

  • Competing trash days with recycling pick up days as we grow. We will be starting out on Saturdays to help curb this problem, but as we grow we might have to add days.
  • Figuring fuel cost for pick ups. Strategically routing pick ups and people joining from different parts of town at first is difficult to calculate.

Other Ways You Can Help

The main thing we ask is, if you are interested and want to join us in our mission, please pledge and share this on all social media platforms. We believe this will be an asset to our city for years to come.

story:
"You can't get it" they are telling me. But I knew that WE CAN.

We are creating a prototype of a place where everyone can see and try a combination of tradition with the latest technology in practice. We are building an example of an autonomous community supposed for sustainable and fulfilled living.

The main goal is to show the combination of natural principles with high-tech science in a form that is open for the general public so that each visitor can take on new knowledge and experiences. It is a concept that combines a research center, indoor and open gardens, an educational center, a museum, a science park and a place to relax and fun.

It is based on the idea that everyone learns best through their own experiences and we use informal methods while trying to allow all visitors to try everything out and come up with the principle that things work.  There are workshops like painting, pottery, blacksmith, carpenter, electronics, and visitors can even make and take their products.

This project would be also inspiration for others and with some modifications would be build up everywhere on Earth. We don't want to push somebody somewhere. We want to provide space and tools for creative people because we believe that ancient deficiencies such as wars, poverty, hunger, debts and unnecessary human suffering are perceived as inevitable, but it is unacceptable. It is high time to learn from these shortcomings, stemming from ignorance and false faith. 
It's time to start working together and not competing. 

What We Need & What You Get

  • Your support is important because all of you will help us to reach our goal and each of you will be part of this project
  • All of the funding will be used for buying building material and technological parts
  • Every supporter will obtain unique code which can be used for buying products or services in value of donation
  • You can follow us in Update section for progress info. 
  • All of the activities will be also recorded and shared on social media as a open source project
  • We hope that you all understand the possibilities and impact of this project and there is big "THANK YOU" for all of our supporters

 

Elize offers space for regeneration and relaxation in various forms. There are spaces suitable for smaller concerts, lectures, yoga or meditation exercises.

Yet man is a creative creature and for many of us, relaxation is creation. Painting, pottery, music, wood or metal products. Various artistic small items as well as technological equipment. 

We offer space and the possibility of realization for people with common interests. There are various craft but also hi-tech workshops, atelier, music studio as well as covered gardens with year-round possibility of growing vegetables and herbs. 

 

Year-round use brings challenges in the form of the need to find different technical solutions from the actual overlapping of spaces, through the provision of energy, thermal comfort, water, waste and everything that proves necessary. 

The current market offers a number of solutions but our aim is to connect and possibly design and produce the most suitable components for maximum efficiency. 

Our goal is to achieve energy independence and therefore we focus on research and development in Elize such as solar and wind power, energy storage, space heating and cooling, lighting, irrigation, but of course also equipment such as electric bicycles, hovercraft, decomposition equipment. water, 3D printing, virtual reality or robotics.

 

Sample buildings provide a detailed view of the possibilities of connecting technologies so that the residents have the same comfort as in classic houses but with zero costs. As it is said, it is better to see how one hundred times you hear. 

The current trend is to return to natural materials and our effort is to build examples of buildings such as timber, house of clay, house of pressed hemp or Earthship.

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute this doesn't mean you can not help!

You can share the post and make some noise about our campaign or join us on ground  :)

story:
WE NO LONGER REQUIRE FUNDING! THANK YOU ALL FOR YOUR SUPPORT AND GOD BLESS :-)
Sincerely, 
World Biotechnology

We wanted to produce photosynthetic chicken. This of course is impossible using conventional methods. Thus, we tried something different and "Direct-Light" Technology was born. We quickly realized that "Direct-Light" Technology can do a lot more than just produce photosynthetic animals that can serve as low cost food for the world. "Direct-Light" Technology can produce renewable and sustainable commercially viable biofuel, hydrogen fuel, electric power, better vehicles, and the list goes on.


http://ns.gmnews.com/news/2011-08-25/Front_Page/Twins_go_from_GEDs_to_Columbia_University.html

http://www.linkedin.com/pub/eugene-dinescu/88/9b/600

http://columbia.academia.edu/VincentDinescu

http://www.linkedin.com/pub/vincent-dinescu/43/952/755

http://www.quovadisnewspaper.com/twins-enroll-at-columbia-university-with-a-boost-from-mcc-1.2616527

Who we are

We are twin brothers and have been working together for most of our lives. Delineating our roles and responsibilities came naturally. It just seemed wisest and most logical to separate roles and responsibilities based on our strengths and interests. Eugene possesses a strong ability to lead and is more focused on overall company vision while Vincent is also a leader but enjoys a more hands on strategy in order to run day-to-day operations and management. We are both specialists in the science.
Most impressive accomplishment

Our mother was diagnosed with cancer, we did not have any health insurance at the time, and we were losing our home. Vincent and I decided to drop out of H.S. so that we can work and take care of everything. We succeeded, our mother has been in remission since 2007, we saved the house, got GEDs, were featured in the news, and got accepted to Columbia University. Acquired enough credits to graduate with honors in 3 years but decided to continue to take more advanced science courses and research.


Product

Direct-Light” Technology is the world’s 1st renewable energy platform that delivers an immediate solution for increasing profit margins, sustainability, and commercial viability for manufacturers of biofuel (1st, 2nd, 3rd, and 4th generations including biopropane), food (animal and animal based food products), hydrogen fuel, feed, and fertilizer. Our patented “Direct-Light” Technology can also be implemented in a long list of additional industries including crop, electrical power, and computer. Unlike the current biotechnology companies, ”Direct-Light” Technology provides a green solution that can effectively replace all of the current primary technology platforms. Additionally, we have developed our patented “Green Technology Cycle”. This cycle replaces nonrenewable modes of energy production and also drastically outcompetes them for a fraction of the cost while also minimizing any waste. Our customers include manufacturers of biofuel, food, hydrogen fuel, feed, fertilizer, etc.

Technology

Invented & patented "Direct-Light" Technology and the "Green Technology Cycle". "Direct-Light" Technology utilizes a unique cellular machine. This machine can be trangenically added into any organism to produce commercially viable biofuel, photosynthetic animals (food), and supercharged crops. Additionally, this machine can be coupled to any electrical or mechanical device to produce energy via our primary action mechanism. With "Direct-Light" Technology we can produce a renewable electrical generator that can power entire cities with minimal cost. "Direct-Light" Technology possesses an enormous potential with an ever-increasing list of applications. It leaves every scientist awestruck and several of Columbia's top researchers believe that it will be the key energy platform of the future. What truly sets us apart from all other biotechnology and energy companies is the fact that our energy platform is the world's 1st multi-industry disruptive innovation.

Customers

"Direct-Light" Technology drastically reduces costs (more profit) in all of the following: Biofuel Manufacturers: 1st, 2nd, 3rd, and 4th Gen. & Biopropane. About 200 key players in Biofuel industry. Food Manufacturers: Animals (chicken, pig, cow, and fish). Initially focus on US broiler Chicken. 40 key players in this market and all are potential customers. Feed Manufacturers, Fertilizer Manufacturers, Hydrogen Fuel Companies, Electric Power Companies, Crop Manufacturers, Medical Device Companies, Computer Companies, Vehicle Manufacturers, Aviation Companies, and Aerospace Companies.

Distribution

Our business model employs a simple licensing strategy that maximizes both global impact and profitability. World Biotechnology aims to work with select companies that have a strong desire to make a positive difference in the world by using our “Direct-Light” Technology. Basic 2014-2018 Plan: Biofuel License technology Food License technology Hydrogen Fuel License technology Feed & Fertilizer Obtain percentage of sales via the “Green Technology Cycle” byproducts (feed & fertilizer) Note: We can license our technology to a lot more industries.

Current “Direct-Light” Technologies with Selected Advantages

1. Biofuel: Commercially viable 1st, 2nd, 3rd, 4th Gen, and Biopropane. Our fuels are produced through light via our primary action mechanism. Simple and easy and most importantly, extremely cheap.

2. Food: “Direct-Light” animals that increase profits via less feed requirement-photosynthetic.

3. Hydrogen-Fuel: Renewable energy.

4. Feed: Our system saves arable land by using byproducts.

5. Fertilizer: Same simple system saves arable land & reduces toxicity.

6. Crop: Supercharged crops!

7. Crop-Drug: Soil enhancer increases growth rate via “Direct-Light” mechanism. Non-GMO!

8. Electrical-Generator: Power for entire cities.

9. Electrical-Battery

10. Computer

11. Virtual-CPU

12. LCD-Display

13. Disease-Microscope

14. Stem-Cells

15. Rocket

16. Satellite-System

17. Vehicle

18. Airbag

19. Hovercraft-Station

20. Commercial-Plane

21. Ultra-Jet

Risks and challenges

World Biotechnology Risks & Challenges

1. Intellectual Property

Our success depends, at least in part, on our ability to protect our proprietary technology as well as our intellectual property. To succeed here, we rely on a combination of patent applications, trade secrets, including know-how, employee and third party nondisclosure agreements, trademarks, intellectual property licenses and other contractual rights. This allows us to establish and protect our proprietary rights in our technology. So far we have over 200 pending claims. These intellectual property claims cover different aspects of our technology, and many of them have been or will be filed both in the United States and in various foreign jurisdictions. We intend to continue to file additional patent applications related to our technology platform with a strong emphasis on protecting our core technologies. As is the situation with all patent application filing, we do not know whether our pending patent applications will materialize into issuance of patents or whether the examination process will necessitate us to narrow our claims. Despite the fact that there can be no guarantee that these pending patent applications, if granted, will provide us with complete protection, our management of these filings is highly focused on maximizing the possibility of securing the strongest patent protection available.

Our precautions may not prevent misappropriation or infringement of our patented technology platform and related intellectual property. Third parties could infringe or misappropriate our patents, copyrights, trademarks, trade secrets, and a wide range of other proprietary rights. Litigation may be needed to enforce our intellectual property rights, to protect our trade secrets, to determine the validity and range of the proprietary rights of others or to defend against claims of infringement, invalidity, misappropriation or other possible claims. Any such litigation could result in substantial costs and diversion of our resources. Moreover, any type of settlement of or negative judgment resulting from such litigation could restrict or prohibit our use other technology. Our inadequacy or inability to properly protect our intellectual property or to defend against third-part infringement claims could potentially harm our business.

If external party patents or other intellectual property rights cover any of our processes, products or derived technologies, we could be subject to various legal actions. As a result of this reality that all biotechnology and technology companies face, we can assure you that our technology and products do not infringe patents held by others or that will not in the future. The bottom line is that litigation is costly and time consuming, and there can be no assurance that our litigation expenses will not be high in the future or that we will be victorious in any such litigation.

2. Regulatory Approvals

There are many approvals required for a number of our applications and due to this our technology platform may be delayed. Government approvals are required and we are in the process of working with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, or the EPA, to ensure that we receive the proper approvals for our biofuel technology. Additionally, we are in the process of securing approvals globally and within all of our industries working with analogous agencies such as the FDA for food.

3. Research and Development

Our research and development team is highly motivated and primarily focused on the continued advancement of our technology platform to maximize the value within all of our industries. We believe that we will continue to improve and develop our platform. In order to ensure this we will devote significant expenditures to research and development. Without proper research and development with well-invested resources allocated to our efforts we will not be able to succeed.

4. Competition

In the short-term, we expect that we will have several potential competitors in several of our industries: established enterprises and new companies that seek to produce renewable fuels or renewable energy. In the long-term, we believe that our Biofuel will compete with petroleum-based fuels within the transportation fuels market. 
We believe that the primary competitive factors in the renewable energy market are: 
o The scope of qualification 
o Compatibility with existing infrastructure 
o Product performance and quality 
o Product price 
o Ability to produce commercial volume 
o Reliability 
We believe that the primary factors in the global market are: 
o Product performance and quality 
o Overall Price 
o Commercialization 
o Reliability 
Given the size of our overall market and even the individual markets such as the traditional transportation fuels market we do not believe that the success of other renewable products will prevent us from being successful. However, we must be mindful that it is important for us to reach potential customers and convince them that our technology platform and derived technologies and products are effective and the best choice based on qualification, compatibility, price, commercialization, and reliability. The positive nature of our business is that we intend to license our technology to essentially all of our competitors. This means that our competitors are also our customers. This way we eliminate risk and greatly mitigate the challenge of facing well-establish enterprises and companies.

5. Environmental and Other Regulatory Matters

Our operations are indirectly and directly affected by a variety of federal, state and local environmental laws and regulations that could either benefit or hurt us depending on the clauses. Considering that we are entirely green, eco-friendly, and sustainable we expect that these laws will essentially become a strong asset to our technology and company. We have been positively supported by a wide range of laws and acts, such as the CAA, CERCLA, Clean Water Act, RCRA, and the Toxic Substances Control Act. We anticipate that laws and acts will continue to pass that favor technologies and companies that are similar to us.

6. Seasonality

We do not expect that the demand for our technology platform, derived technologies, or products from our technology will be subject to seasonality. However, prices for certain supplies that we may use for our technology and business can be subject to seasonal changes.

7. Employees

All of our employees are located in the United States. None of our employees are represented by a labor union or covered by a collective bargaining agreement. We have never had any experience of employment-related stoppages, and we strongly believe that our employee relationships will continue to be very good.

Risks Related to Our Business and Industries

1. We are a development stage company. We have not generated any significant revenue and our business will not accomplish its goals if we are not able to commercialize successfully on our technology platform within at least one of our primary industries.

We are subject to the typical risk of failure facing any business that is seeking to develop new products or technologies. Certain factors that could, alone or in combination, prevent us from achieving commercialization within one or all of our industries include: 
• Technical challenges developing our commercial production at late stage that was unable to overcome 
• Ability to finance our complete plan with standard production of our headquarters, laboratory, and facilities. 
• Ability to achieve large scale production on a cost-effective basis and in the time frame that we set out 
• Ability to secure and maintain loyal customers that will purchase our technology platform and related technologies in licensing agreements 
• Ability to produce our technology platform to customer specifications in a related industry 
• Ability to secure access to sufficient material resources and supplies that are economically priced for our business 
• Changes in government regulations and policies affecting one of our industries 
• Ability to secure and maintain all required regulatory approvals 
• Actions by indirect or direct competitors that may seek to impose barriers to one or more of our industries

2. We need substantial capital in order to meet our operating and other costs.

As with any business, we require a set amount or fixed cost in order to successfully operate. Fortunately, we require much less than the typical biotechnology company. However, our costs are still substantial due to the necessary research and development that will be required within each of our industries. We will need to hire top-level personnel and will require a state-of-the-art lab in order to function properly.

3. In the early stage of our business we will be vulnerable to disruptions to our operations as is any business that functions solely in a single first-of-kind facility.

In order to achieve steady-state operations at our facility, it will be required to perform periodic maintenance and turnarounds. We will try limiting the portion of the facility that may be disrupted during this maintenance however we cannot predict how much maintenance will be needed or the type of disruption that will result. Any significant disruption can affect the facilities operations however it should not affect revenues and cash flows greatly since we are a licensing based company.

Operations may also be interrupted by electricity, natural gas, water treatment or other utilities. Other potentially disruptive events include natural disasters, inclement weather, workplace or environmental accidents, mechanical failure, fires, explosions, supply interruptions, work stoppage, losses of permits or authorization or acts of terrorism. Some of these events have the potential to cause loss of life, severe damage to or destruction of private or personal property and equipment and environmental damage, and may result in the cessation of operations and the problems of civil or criminal penalties. These are all standard concerns for any business and we cannot provide any assurance that we will not incur losses related to these or other events beyond the limits or exceeding the scope of coverage from our insurance policies.

4. We have no experience producing “Direct-Light” Technology at the scale needed for the development of our business to commercial scale.

We must display our ability to apply our proprietary technology platform and process design at a large enough scale to secure commercialization.

5. The actual cost of constructing, operating and maintaining the facility or facilities necessary to produce our “Direct-Light” Technology platform in each of our industries at commercial volume may be significantly higher than we plan or anticipate.

If and when our facility or facilities are constructed, our costs for operations and maintenance may be significantly higher than we predicted. Additionally, our facilities may not operate as efficiently as we expect. As a result, our initial facility for commercial production of our “Direct-Light” Technology platform may not be able to achieve expectation and there will not be able achieve our expected investment return, which could negatively affect our business and results. Fortunately, we have a large number of industries that we work within so our risk is lessened.

6. We face challenges in obtaining market acceptance of our “Direct-Light” Technology or we cannot secure the proper customer base.

We intend to market our “Direct-Light” Technology platform to select companies in all of our top industries. We assume that these companies will desire our services based on one single fact: we reduce production costs. This means that these companies will increase profits working with us. This is completely logical however sometimes unpredictable behavior or conditions can arise in the marketplace and we cannot guarantee that expected business practice based on simple margins will naturally occur in all cases.

7. We have limited experience with structuring arrangement with prospective customers for licensing agreements with our “Direct-Light” Technology Platform.

In order for us to license our technology to our potential customers we must negotiate contracts and form business relationships. The companies with which we expect to have customer arrangements with are generally much larger than us and have substantially greater bargaining power than us considering their resources. We do believe that his will not arise as an issue for us because we help these companies improve globally. Additionally, we have secured a strong advising team that is well placed within several of our key companies. Some of our advisors to name a few are former CEOs of top Fortune 500 companies within energy companies that are our prime customers.

8. Growth may place significant demands on our management and our infrastructure.

We may experience large growth within our company and markets. If this occurs we will be required to expand. If we fail to achieve the necessary level of efficiency within our organization as it expands, our business could be harmed.

9. Our operating results may fluctuate in the future. As a result, we may fail to achieve or exceed the expectations of research analysts or investors.

Key factors for this will be: 
• Timing of milestones 
• Profitability 
• Feasibility 
• Management 
• Fluctuations in prices within our industries 
• Availability 
• Government programs, incentives, and regulations 
• Reporting 
• Dependence on key management and personnel 
• Ability to obtain, protect and enforce intellectual property rights 
• Advantages of working with us 
• Ability to obtain additional capital if needed 
• Business interruptions 
• Compliance 
• Handling of materials

Eugene possesses a strong ability to lead and is more focused on overall company vision while Vincent is also a leader but enjoys a more hands on strategy in order to run day-to-day operations and management. We are both specialists in the science.Most impressive accomplishmentOur mother was diagnosed with cancer, we did not have any health insurance at the time, and we were losing our home. Vincent and I decided to drop out of H.S. so that we can work and take care of everything. story:
Save Durable Dish

We provide reusable, durable dishes to ready-to-eat food vendors at our market.  This prevents 90 gallons of disposable, single use utensils and dishes from entering the waste stream every market.  This is made possible through a generous community partnership with Thatcher's, who allows us access to their commercial kitchen's dishwashing facilities.

Durable Dish is in jeopardy.  The volunteer supply has been thin at best since the program launched in 2009 and in 2012 it dwindled. The program has been made feasible by individuals who have shouldered a heavy burden season by season, requiring unsustainable levels of effort.  The choice between burning out scarce volunteers and providing inconsistent durable dish service is not a viable one.

To keep Durable Dish alive in 2013, we need to fund two staff positions to staff the dish return station and wash dishes during the after market on Sundays.  This will make the experience of durable dish reliable and consistent for vendors and customers.  

In 2010, Durable Dish won the Association of Oregon Recyclers' Alice Soderwall Reuse and Waste Prevention Award.  It has also received national attention (click here for the Trash or Treasure blog post).  To date the program has saved about 31,802 pieces of waste! It started as a small pilot project in 2009 (funded by City of Portland Bureau of Planning and Sustainability Portland Recycles! Small Grants Program), and in a way is a victim of its own success-- it has so positive of an impact and is so well loved that we can't let it go.

All reports are that the community loves the program.  We understand that the community is not that willing to support it by showing up to haul and wash icky dishes--this has been demonstrated by years of experience.  We hope instead the community will support it by chipping in to fund these positions.

What We Need & What You Get

We need $10/hour for the hours during and after market, payroll expenses, and the other small costs of employing the two individuals.  We will also need to cover the Indiegogo fees, credit card processing fees, and the cost of the rewards.  We already have the dishes.

We have come up with a series of rewards that will only be made available through this campaign.  The sticker, t-shirt, and bag will not be for sale at the market.  In fact, they will only get created if the campaign funds.

Funds raised above and beyond the goal will be held in the market's accounts to fund durable dish staff in future years.  If funds raised exceed $5,000, those excess funds will go to the market's general fund, to support innovative sustainable practices at our market.

Why This Matters

The culture of single-use, disposable comsumer items is bad for the planet.  

Without this funding we will be forced to cease Durable Dish, and revert to, at best, compostables.  This represent 90+ gallons of waste per market Sunday.

Given the value of our community, we should be able to band together and make this program viable.

How Else to Help

Share this campaign with friends, blog about it, and discuss it in your community.

If you are interested in one of the positions, watch our newsletter, Facebook page, and blog for an announcement if the campaign funds.

About Montavilla Farmers Market

We are a small to medium farmers market in SE Portland's Montavilla neighborhood.  We operate June through October, with select additional winter dates including the Sunday before Thanksgiving, at the 7600 block of SE Stark.

The mission of the Montavilla Farmers Market is to provide a vibrant marketplace where our diverse community has access to high quality, local, healthy food. We create opportunities for our vendors and customers to support and learn from each other, which strengthens our local economy.

To learn more about us, visit our website!

Frequently Asked Questions?

Why not just use compostables?  Aren't they green?

It's true that compostable serviceware does not contain fossil fuels like plastics do and that they can break down into compost after they're thrown away if they are processed in the right kind of facility. However, the production and distribution of compostable serviceware still requires fossil fuels. Growing crops for compostable "bioplastics" takes up land on the planet's limited space available for growing food crops. Bioplastic items are hard to recognize compared to regular plastics. Many bioplastics end up mixed into plastics recycling by mistake, causing contamination of recycling. There are limited commercial compost facilities in the U.S. to process these items properly, so they often end up in the landfill where they do not actually compost at all, but instead eventually break down and produce methane, a more potent greenhouse gas than carbon dioxide. Given all these factors, truly the most sustainable choice is to become a culture that chooses to reuse what we have rather than continue to produce and consume disposable items into perpetuity no matter what the cost to the planet.

You don't need staff do do this-- can I just volunteer?

We expect people will want to offer to volunteer-- this is great! There are many volunteer roles available at the market that we would be happy to discuss with you.  However, we've been at this since 2009 now, and we know how durable dish management works out with exclusively volunteer based support.  It requires highly accountable staff positions to execute it.

Why don't you fund this by raising vendor fees?

Our vendors, both in ready-to-eat food and our farmers, are small, and in many cases new businesses struggling to exist.  We do not think it is a viable option for our market to put the burden of this program that benefits the entire planet on their shoulders.  We hope the community that values Durable Dish will help pay for Durable Dish.

Why are rewards so expensive?

We want to money here to primarily go to the cause, not to printing t-shirts.  The rewards are little thank yous for a donation, not a purchase themselves.
story_txt:
Save Durable Dish
We provide reusable, durable dishes to ready-to-eat food vendors at our market.  This prevents 90 gallons of disposable, single use utensils and dishes from entering the waste stream every market.  This is made possible through a generous community partnership with Thatcher's, who allows us access to their commercial kitchen's dishwashing facilities.
Durable Dish is in jeopardy.  The volunteer supply has been thin at best since the program launched in 2009 and in 2012 it dwindled. The program has been made feasible by individuals who have shouldered a heavy burden season by season, requiring unsustainable levels of effort.  The choice between burning out scarce volunteers and providing inconsistent durable dish service is not a viable one.
To keep Durable Dish alive in 2013, we need to fund two staff positions to staff the dish return station and wash dishes during the after market on Sundays.  This will make the experience of durable dish reliable and consistent for vendors and customers.  
In 2010, Durable Dish won the Association of Oregon Recyclers' Alice Soderwall Reuse and Waste Prevention Award.  It has also received national attention (click here for the Trash or Treasure blog post).  To date the program has saved about 31,802 pieces of waste! It started as a small pilot project in 2009 (funded by City of Portland Bureau of Planning and Sustainability Portland Recycles! Small Grants Program), and in a way is a victim of its own success-- it has so positive of an impact and is so well loved that we can't let it go.


All reports are that the community loves the program.  We understand that the community is not that willing to support it by showing up to haul and wash icky dishes--this has been demonstrated by years of experience.  We hope instead the community will support it by chipping in to fund these positions.

What We Need & What You Get
We need $10/hour for the hours during and after market, payroll expenses, and the other small costs of employing the two individuals.  We will also need to cover the Indiegogo fees, credit card processing fees, and the cost of the rewards.  We already have the dishes.
We have come up with a series of rewards that will only be made available through this campaign.  The sticker, t-shirt, and bag will not be for sale at the market.  In fact, they will only get created if the campaign funds.
Funds raised above and beyond the goal will be held in the market's accounts to fund durable dish staff in future years.  If funds raised exceed $5,000, those excess funds will go to the market's general fund, to support innovative sustainable practices at our market.


Why This Matters
The culture of single-use, disposable comsumer items is bad for the planet.  
Without this funding we will be forced to cease Durable Dish, and revert to, at best, compostables.  This represent 90+ gallons of waste per market Sunday.
Given the value of our community, we should be able to band together and make this program viable.


How Else to Help
Share this campaign with friends, blog about it, and discuss it in your community.
If you are interested in one of the positions, watch our newsletter, Facebook page, and blog for an announcement if the campaign funds.

The mission of the Montavilla Farmers Market is to provide a vibrant marketplace where our diverse community has access to high quality, local, healthy food. We create opportunities for our vendors and customers to support and learn from each other, which strengthens our local economy.
To learn more about us, visit our website!

Bioplastic items are hard to recognize compared to regular plastics. Many bioplastics end up mixed into plastics recycling by mistake, causing contamination of recycling. There are limited commercial compost facilities in the U.S. to process these items properly, so they often end up in the landfill where they do not actually compost at all, but instead eventually break down and produce methane, a more potent greenhouse gas than carbon dioxide. story:
Summary

Parks Permaculture Farm is a 10 acre sustainable farm and education center in Parks, Arizona.  Scott Ross, Dan Burke and many other key contributors have been working to establish and build the farm since August, 2017.

  •  An Earthbag structure onsite will serve a utilitarian purpose but more importantly it will be the centerpiece of sustainable architecture and an educational tool to local and internet communities.

Fundraiser Goal: $4000

Funds will go towards the following(we already have the bags):

  • gravel for foundation (stem wall)
  • 1 wood door with frame and 4 windows with arched wood frame
  • reciprocal wooden roof frame with turf (living roof)
  • 4 point Barbed Wire (serves as mortar for earthbags)
  • homemade rocket mass heater
  • hardware (bolts, nails, ties etc - primarily for roof)
  • lunch for workshop volunteers (Aug. 18th & 25th) 

The Impact

We want very much for this project to launch a much larger movement of earthbag construction in the area and are excited to see it through! 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please attend the free Earthbag Building Workshops on Aug. 18th and 25th out at the Parks Permaculture Farm from 9am - 4pm.  Come for a portion or for the duration, it's up to you!
